headline: Great company, difficult to navigate
pros: Opportunity to work with and learn from awesome, smart people. ample opportunities for learning from cross-functional teams, through internal interest groups and courses. Inclusive workplace. GREAT perks (the meals, beautiful campuses, flexible hybrid work model).
cons: Very self-service oriented, meaning you have to learn things and navigate the org pretty much on your own. Very hard to get promoted, which can be demoralizing for some.

headline: Great overall company culture, but it comes down to your team
pros:
Excellent employee benefits and competitive salary (usually the top of the market)
Lots of opportunity for professional growth and internal mobility
Perks are fantastic (free food, onsite gym, shuttle service, etc.)
cons: I'm sure you've read all the great things about working at Google, such as the obvious like perks and salary. But do your due diligence when going through the interview process to get a feel for your team and manager. Ultimately, that is what is going to shape your day to day experience at the company. I ultimately left after a bad re-org that left me doing the work of 4-5 people by myself that was outside the scope of my level, yet I wasn't promoted when I brought it up to my manager.

headline: Good pay, working environment. Google is not the same as it was 10 years ago though.
pros: Freedom in working style and good pay. Rewarding work if you find a team that is a good fit.
cons:
It's getting harder to take pride in the work as products decline and get shut down. Promo rewards new products and features rather than quality.

It's also harder than it used to be to move teams. Popular teams get a lot of people applying, and a lot of teams interview almost as if you are changing companies.

Unless you do ML, there is not much room for growth in a purely technical role. You have to shift into more of a leadership role.

headline: The Best Culture & Outstanding Compensation
pros:
Google is very generous with the total compensation (TC), which is composed of:

1.) Highly competitive base salary depending on your "Level." 
2.) Annual bonus (40% of base) 
3.) Equity (front-loaded 33%/33%/22%/12%)
4.) Sign-on bonus
5.) Relocation package

Cool perks: Googleplex gym, free food (3 meals a day + snacks + drinks), 50% 401k matching up to $19,500, hybrid work model (MF at home, TWTH in office), PTO, education reimbursement, internet & phone reimbursement, massage chairs & nap pods, cool office spaces with different themed rooms (Harry Potter, etc.), bikes and scooters to get around campus 

Everyone at Google is intelligent, helpful, and friendly. The best part is diversity and inclusion. I've never felt safer being different, sharing unique ideas, and being myself at any other organization. 

The leaders and my peers constantly challenge me to grow in more ways than I can imagine. There are different programs for mentorship, which helped me discover my career path. I feel supported here, and the kindness of my team is genuine, and I feel like everyone wants to help each other.
cons: It's a big tech company, so it takes more time to make an impact vs. a tech start-up. There are politics and nuances to getting promoted, but that's a given with any big corporation.

headline: Very mixed experience
pros:
The product my team is building is very important to Google. I am very happy to work in this team with my smart and excellent peers.
If you are a new grad or need to spend time taking care of your family, Google is an excellent company in terms of WLB, cutting edge technology. If you have something you truly passionate about, go for it! Do not waste your valuable time for the working experiethe in a big name.
cons:
But Google moves very slow, all the things are about reliability and stableness, which is very important though. I haven't seen exciting project for years.

The food is not good anymore. Allhands have been more and more boring. I don't buy the story the executives depicted. I doubt they believe in what they pitched.

headline: Nothing beyond the brand name
pros:
- Google offers you the best tech you will need to do your job successfully. You get to choose your own laptop and phone and they send you nice swag every few weeks.
- You learn how to work at scale
- Work with great team mates, the best in the business
cons:
- Work life balance. #LifeAtGoogle becomes your life altogether, you may not have time for anything else. #LifeOutsideGoogle is non existent
- High pressure. Google is growing at a pace faster than they can handle themselves. Growing rapidly entails right sizing teams to cater to an increased workload, this was not the case. Google will make you over work and then send you a bunch of goodies, but beyond a point, goodies don't do justice to the work that they get out of you.
- Hitting your high pressure hiring target is one piece, apart from that, you ought to be exceptional at your SLA's, TTH and Pass Through Rates. With high volume hiring, meeting all the requirements can be very daunting.
- As part of the interview process, was made to meet with a Senior leader on the recruitment team, and the individual did nothing but humiliate me. Wasn't sure if that was the intent, to break someone down and corner them, but it was the worst feeling, especially when it is a leader

headline: A decent place to work, that could be much better
pros:
Great coworkers
Decent pay
Maybe it will get better
cons:
The company is undervaluing this area. By working anywhere else in the country - Pittsburgh Pa, Rural Virginia -- even 40 miles West to Burlington, NC you would make more money. This does a disservice to the area. The company further claims it is trying to hire more HBCU graduates in this location... So cheapest location in the country, and trying to hire HBCU graduates. Not a good look. The News & Observer and Washington post have both issued articles "Google lowered its salaries in North Carolina. Now workers are protesting" and "Google employees protest company’s Durham wage policy. Here’s why they’re upset"

On a less key note, compared to other google offices, the office here seems surprisingly normal - more akin to your typical office location than you think of when you hear google office. Maybe this isn't a bad thing, but it shouldn't feel so targeted as making this a "discount" location.

headline: Nobody does anything, nobody cares
pros:
Working at Google is extremely chill. The work/life balance is great (although beware meetings with other timezones) and there is a lot of flexibility.

The expectations are almost nil - it's impossible to get fired, unless you completely stop showing up.

The benefits and pay are good (not the best in the industry, but better than most).

Some of the older technology was (and sometimes still is) genuinely groundbreaking. You can learn a lot by studying it. If you're an engineer, find someone senior who has been there for 10+ years to learn from: most of those people are extremely impressive, if they haven't left yet.
cons:
Most of the senior leadership changed from 2015 to about 2018, and the new people are the most "meh" uninspiring bunch of caretakers I've ever seen. Above director level, leadership seems to only care about PR and cutting costs - nobody has any kind of product vision or the guts to try anything new. Any innovative product someone manages to produce gets killed immediately. Any new acquisitions get bogged down in senseless bureaucracy.

The old leadership leaving triggered a chain reaction that's still ongoing, and has now reached tech lead and line manager levels. Most of the best people left or mostly checked out.

There's nothing wrong with wanting a simple 9-5 job, but Google today is something else: it's soul-crushing how much nobody cares anymore, and how disincentivized you are from actually trying to ship a product for end-users. If you actually try to get anything done, you will be the only one, and it'll suck life out of you.

On paper, this might sound like a nice, chill gig, but human beings are not meant to do nothing. The complete lack of goals or vision in the company will start getting to you sooner or later, and it is depressing.

Consider: this is a well-funded business with lots of infrastructure and resources, and the leadership chooses to do absolutely nothing with them.

headline: Adapt to the elitist environment and you have a safe place to rest with average comp+perks
pros:
- Hard to get fired with easy work and weak underperforming colleagues to measure up to.
- Free food - not great - but "free".
- Come here to rest [strikeout]and vest[/strikeout].
cons:
- The average developer in Google is a far shot from being a great engineer despite all the "prestige". This reflects in an aging tech stack, poor code quality, overcomplicated designs that are glorified in a self-fulfulling game of showing off how much complexity engineers can come up with. Surprisingly sketchy practices on some core products. A lot of the 10+ yoe engineers here have been at no other company and know little of the outside world or technology progress.
- This company is super frugal - to the point of being just plain cheap. This is a far shot from the reputation it has of having extraordinary perks and a fun environment to work at. Offices are very average for today's standards even compared to much smaller companies. Management dumps corpspeak on Googlers every other week and feels old school corporatey. Open memegen (the company's internal 9gag) any day of the week to see popular posts endlessly complaining about compensation, corpspeak from leadership, lack of transparency and overall self-mocking messages. It's pretty depressing and nothing ever changes.
- Systematic racism + extreme in-your-face diversity consciousness advertising makes this a painfully hypocritical company to work for.
- As an engineer who myself enjoys the guilty pleasure of an occasional praise, being surrounded by Googlers' continuous self praising and elitism is repulsive. Stick around employees a bit after a few drinks and you'll open up a secret world made up of an openly dirty racist bunch of humans lusting for more money and status (or might just be the London office).
- Shady HR and recruitment divisions are with aggressive under the belt tactics for hiring and retention.

cons: A lot of privileged/entitled employees. Most people are lovely (Google has a great culture) but all of the angst comes from people who are job-hoppers and prioritize salary over everything. headline: Good company with decaying culture/compensation
pros:
- You'll work with very smart people
- The stock performs very well (generally)
- Decent work / life balance
- Great benefits
- Great stepping stone for your career
cons:
- RTO policy is stupid (cutting as much as 25% base salary for employees wanting to stay remote)
- Compensation no longer top of market (This has been the case since even before the pandemic. eg.) Stripe, Netflix, Instacart, The TradeDesk all pay much better)
- Lots of red tape and not much room for making impact
- There has been a noticeable shift in culture since the pandemic where you feel like a cog in a giant machine that doesn't care about you. Mass emails talking about policy, upper management out of touch with employees, and a common problem where you ask a question in chat and no one replies.
- Good luck getting in touch with an HR rep if you ever have an issue and actually need to talk to one

cons: None, none, none, none, none.

headline: Old fashioned tech company where office politics work
pros:
The pay and benefits are great. On most teams, work you do influences many, many people. The company is huge. If you aren't happy on your team, it's easy to find another one and transfer, much easier than if you were unhappy at a startup and had to move to a whole new company. Changing teams is as easy as clicking a few buttons, a short chat with the new manager, and filling out a form. Relative to anywhere else I've worked, people are more positive and helpful, nearly always willing to make time to help each other out.

Google has many products that have millions or billions of customers. It's easy to find teams that give you the opportunity to develop skills to work at huge scales. Relative to other companies, it's simple to write servers or single-use or cron applications that process huge amounts of data and do it securely, with respect for user data. You can learn how to store massive quantities of data for customers in geographically disparate areas and respect data-location and privacy laws or learn how to apply AI queries at scale while respecting user privacy or write UIs that run on many different types of devices and screens. The scale of the company provides many, many opportunities.
cons:
Engineering processes and tools are ancient and bad, but people in charge believe that those practices are the key to Google's past and future success. Compilation, testing, deployment are painful slow and error-prone. Engineers aren't permitted to code on laptops. Everything from the version control system to the build tool to the server frameworks to the server environment is internal-only and custom. It feels like the dark ages. The company in the 2020s introduced the first team-based work planner with a backlog and iterations.

Working hard and improving the product and company doesn't get you promoted. You have to spend time selling yourself and your work. The amount of time you'll spend doing that varies by team. Some engineers do practically no work and are great at getting bonuses and promoted. They attach themselves to multiple other teams, organize big meetings, give presentations and that's about all. Most other companies ferret those people out quickly. Google promotes them.

To clarify my "Diversity & Inclusion" score, the company could not possibly do more. I was on a team that held multiple college recruiting events only for women, black, and latinx students. There were empty seats and we threw food away. One of the professors, a woman, emailed almost begging to let a few other students in. Internally, there are promotion opportunities only available to people based on their gender or race. When we start discriminating unnecessarily, that's not "inclusion". It's explicitly "exclusion".

headline: Hard to change job ladders
pros: An abundance of free perks: good, gyms, discounted massages, great offices
cons:
Google makes it incredibly hard to change job ladders. I have done an absurd amount of 20% projects across various teams to sharpen my skill sets, and have been looking for a new non-administrative job for three years now (of my nearly four year tenure) and have not gotten one offer. I have more than seventy closed applications for roles that I am more than qualified for. It has come down to me and another candidate numerous times now, and I’m constantly told that I do not have enough experience, when I clearly do. 

If you don’t want to grow your career in a significant way, this is a great place, but if you do, you should think twice about working here.

headline: culture
pros:
Pro: Animals Welcome.

Many Google offices are animal friendly. The most extreme example is their California office which makes use of goats to keep their lawns neatly grazed, but many other offices also encourage their staff to bring their dogs to work, to improve wellbeing. Another initiative also provides pushbikes to ride around the Google Campus in an eco-friendly way.
cons:
Con: Work-life balance – not always balanced.

Many modern American companies have developed a contrived culture of lingering at work. Ambitious, new or young talent may end up hanging out at the office outside of work hours, often working or learning. This can develop into peer pressure to spend a lot of time at the office. Apart from coffee shops and libraries, some places have “sleep pods” for that swift power nap to help you keep going for longer. The Toronto Office even has a crazy golf putting green on the roof!

headline: Google is a great place to work
pros:
basic affiliation - people are impressed when they learn you work for Google.

- compensation - it's no secret how far ahead of market comp they are. Ask any non-Google company in the valley that has made an offer to a Googler.

- the quality of people around you - have we beaten this one to death?

- the borderline unbelievable perks. See articles about their life insurance benefits, for just one extreme example.
cons:
The first 3 months at Google are a honeymoon, the first 2 years are great, then it goes downhill from there.

Performance management is a massive unsolved problem. There is the expectation that the expectations you have to meet keep growing forever so it's hard to take a break. Even if you don't get promoted, expectations grow because "you're more experienced".

headline: Still an amazing place to work, beware of entitlement
pros:
1. Great work/life balance. There's not many companies I know that have a consistent a 40hr work week, and pay top salary.
2. Cool projects to work on. Good balance between research & development. (See caveats below though.)
3. Supportive, healthy, psychologically safe work environment. Google cares a ton about how we work, and how we work together. The bottom-up culture also means that we have a lot of self-determination and don't feel like we're at the mercy of our management.
4. Super easy internal mobility. Lots of us change teams every couple of years. Google has so many different types of work that you won't feel you're "stuck" -- as long as you like working at Google overall, then you'll be able to find something interesting.
5. It's Google! Having Google on your resume opens doors to other opportunities, and it's great for networking too since generally your colleagues will be top of their field.
cons:
1. Entitlement. I make literally 5x as much as I ever dreamt. The comp is insane at FAANG companies like Google. But people here constantly complain about salary, the quality of the free food, why they have to work 5 days a week.... these are sometimes the same people who work 20 hrs a week. The amount of entitlement is insane here -- yes, we're the best of the best and we deserve a lot. But the culture and perks tend to pamper us.

2. Not all teams and projects have fulfilling work. There's lots of options, but choose carefully. Maybe you're happy getting paid to do nothing, on a team that has no visibility, so that you can "rest and vest" and coast. But, this will leave you woefully unprepared for your next job.... any company will hire you after Google, but that doesn't mean you'll do well at any company, particularly if you go to a more fast paced environment.

headline: Great program to get into Google
pros:
- Free food and snacks
- Excellent benefits (Google gives you $10K per year if you max your 401K)
- Fun coworkers and positive working environment
- Flexible/Hybrid work opportunities
- Learn lots about Cloud and time/budget to attain professional certifications
- Explore both technical and non-technical work
cons:
- Your experience is very dependant on the team you end up rotating with, so mileage may vary. If you end up with a team without much work, you have to actively search around for things to do. On the other hand, if your team is slammed, you will have to learn to say no.

- Information is provided with little warning. The program can be changed on the fly, and you will not know where or in what role you will be placed until a week before it happens

- You begin as an L2, rather than the usual L3

- If you are set on being 100% technical, software engineering may be a better fit. You could try to transfer after this program but I think having software engineering experience at another company will be a better way into Google SWE.

headline: Generic large software company
pros: Interview is fairly easy if you prepare for it. Its very difficult to get fired. Products have so much existing market share that there is very little risk of them getting disrupted even if serious errors are made quarter after quarter.
cons:
Google makes most of its own tooling/libraries/etc and those things break a lot more often than they should - it creates a sense of powerlessness and insignificance because work is often impeded or interrupted when it isn't even your fault and your only recourse is to wait for it to be fixed. Most of the best/preferred technologies are not shared outside the company which limits how much your skill set can transfer to elsewhere.

Policy on covid makes no sense, is highly disruptive to productivity and I don't think its going to get better - most of the world has moved on but Google is still living in a time capsule from early 2020 when it comes to covid.

headline: Great opportunity to level up technically
pros: Effectively unlimited technical growth potential. There is no shortage of challenging technical problems to solve. Good work life balance. Top-notch benefits.
cons: Can suffer from normal big company bureacracy. You might feel like a drone.

headline: Working at Google
pros:
Working at Google was a small part of what makes working there so great.

It was a great day, with awesome people.

I get to spend this week with one of my best friends again.

We will travel from Colorado to Montana for two events: a youth group camp and an AA meeting in Butte.

The night that we were going to drive to Montana, we had a few beers with another girl who we call another girl who we call "T", she's a college friend who lives in Virginia.

After work, we met at a local pub (remember the UK - style pub?

How times have changed.
cons: Deming changed how people think about and work on their own projects and how to mentor their teams. Now, those who’ve worked with him say he’s a gentle, creative soul who seeks to help colleagues. In Google’s Building 8, he and his two deputies offer support to engineers as they work on projects that are often wildly speculative. For instance, “we’ve been doing [research on] brain-machine interfaces,” Deming says. “These are like, crazy new ideas.”

headline: Farm Worker
pros: I have been Worker as a farm worker from 2013 to till now
cons:
I want to apply in an open position of Agriculture worker within your Company. I'm excited about the growth opportunities and hope to explore the contributions I can make .I have a bachelor's degree from National University Bangladesh and over 15 years of hands-on farm experience. 
I live and grew up around fields and learning about agriculture and farming since childhood. My Knowledge of multiple areas includes crops growth, agriculture land management.
Horticulture and landscape management areas. When I started my career. I helped spray beans, rice, corn, potting, irrigation systems. mixing of composed, cleaning water tanks for a mix. sometimes I have to load unload plants on a truck.

I have been working in our own firm since 2010. By side I have been running a pesticide business. I have done a lot of training on agriculture. I have training certificates from many companies. I have a lot of reputation among farmers for understanding crop diseases.

My job has taught me that I don't mind getting my hands dirty and feel the satisfaction of a job well done at the end of long hard day work. Over my diverse career, I have worked to protect and revitalize agriculture, support beginning farmers. and make food systems more vital, interconnected, sustainable and resilient. With an entrepreneurial and collaborative approach. I combine my big-picture vision with on-the-ground know-how to develop innovative projects from ideas to reality. I hope to play an active role in the future prosperity of your organization.
Thank you for time. I'm looking forward to your response

headline: Good WLB is mostly propaganda
pros: Coworkers are generally pretty skilled and hard working compared to other lower tier companies I've been at. Also, the perks and pay are decent.
cons: There's a lot of people online who claim that the WLB at Google is something super amazing and cushy. Don't believe any of that. In practice from what I've seen, the people here generally work a bit more than I've seen at other places. Your number of CLs submitted and the number of lines of code you write are all tracked and very publicly available for everyone and if you fall below a certain threshold be prepared to get called out, which I haven't quite seen at other places. Also the systems here are usually very convoluted and there's generally a lot of boiler plate and config and setup to get even very basic features implemented and working.

headline: Acquisition experience
pros: Lots of free food available
cons:
Inept management of acquisition. Told us we had years of runway, then turned around and dumped it in 2 years, leaving folks to fend for themselves. Promised support from HR was laugably inadequate.

Spent a couple of years looking for a home. To put it mildly, the development culture I found wanting. So much emphasis on coding standards and reviews, for example, but a real lack of planning for the code development in every one of the groups I worked in. Development is not just writing code, but a majority of the engineers I encountered didn’t understand that,

And Perf, the performance review system: what a monster created, albeit with good intentions. Such a massive waste of effort for the gain.

headline: Low Commissions Low  Morall
pros:
Google Fiber is a Great Company Offering a Great Product. 
comes with health insurance and other benefits.
Work as a Vendor Temp instead of doing full time work.
cons:
Compared to other door to door positions the pay is extremely low. 
You are paid between 800 and 1300 every other week depending on your position. with low quarterly bonuses.
It is a year round position which requires knocking in the snow and cold.
The Targets are unrealistic
The team has low moral 

If you are good at door to door there are just better places to go with better commission structures. I have done door to door over 6 years now

headline: Good place to start your career, but don't lose sight of what you truly want
pros:
- Superb, industry leading infrastructure.
- Good internal openness, at least used to have.
- Watch people working on amazing, innovative projects in action.
cons:
- Management either seems unaccountable for their results, e.g. managers doing terrible things to products get promoted; or they seem too focused on quick result, harming Google's reputation and overall product in the process.
- If you lose sight of what you really want to do in life, it is easy to spend a few years at Google being really comfortable, and then realize you are further away from your goals.

headline: Good company (If you’re a fresh grad or want a stable life)
pros: Hands down one of the best tech companies in the world. For a company this size, it’s very progressive and forward thinking. If you’re a fresh grad you’ll learn how to work within a system and learn from some of the best in the business. If you are a very capable person and are tired of grinding at a smaller company, Google is also a great place to cruise. You’ll get decently challenging projects without the stress of having to produce right away. If you’re looking for a big company with good pay, stability and flexibility. Look no further.
cons: If you’re looking for a more challenging job or want to be able to see your impact faster, this is not the place to be. If you prefer to grow into your role instead of being groomed for a role then you’ll have to look elsewhere. As progressive and flat as a big company can be, Google at the end of the day IS still A BIG COMPANY, you will inevitably feel like a cog in a giant machine just like being in any other big companies.

headline: Google Cloud - Google by name not by culture
pros:
- All the Google perks you hear about, although most tech firms offer similar these days
- outside of cloud, Google is a really cool company to work for
- you get to work with some super smart people, especially those who have come from other parts of Google
- Google’s charitable matching program and annual charitable give away to charities of your choice is very cool
cons:
- culture is being destroyed in Cloud through bringing in a stream of people from big consulting companies other less respected tech companies known for terrible culture and practices 
- evidently the talent team sold a lot of pandemic joining nooglers on the future of Google being remote and hired people from all over the UK, yet Cloud have not granted remote working status to hardly anyone, instead everyone has to be in the office three days a week regardless - exodus expected when speaking to colleagues
- despite a core Google value being respect each other, this is not the case in the UK. Bullying and retaliation are a common theme across Cloud. HR seem to bury the cases, as those in management with strings of cases against them seem to regularly get promos. 
- politics and back stabbing are a daily occurrence 
- lots of inexperienced people in management positions making poor decisions 
- performance reviews are every 6 months and are solely based on whether you are part of your managers “in crowd”
- many sales people aren’t hitting target as quotas are extreme/in achievable (don’t believe what you are told in the hiring process)
- Cloud are mainly based in the least desirable Google London office in Victoria 
- pay is not competitive despite what you get told
- the internal sales tools are terrible (there are so many) and not fit for purpose, especially tools for tracking attainment. For a company so focused on data, the Cloud org have no clue how to manage it/make it useable/beneficial internally. you will spend a majority of your day doing admin to make sure you get paid correctly or working out your forecast, which is done in spreadsheets despite all the systems
- there is an annual company survey each year in which Cloud does terribly and every year we are promised change in all the most negative areas, but real change never comes and the issues just get swept under the carpet

headline: Job of my dream a great company
pros:
- Company is growing so there are opportunities that might not immediately exist
- Company provides regular communication, listen to and consider newideas, and
continualiy encouraging growth, both personally and professionally
- Company understands work-life balance and actually respects that
- Culture is conducive to creating friends and mentors with lots of opportunities to get
involved based on your interests
- You get to work with top thought leadersiin several industries — smart, collaborative,
willing to share (you typically don't set such easy 3ccess and support)
cons:
No company is perfect. While we grow, there are things that are evolving (updating.
technology, adding office space, formalizing procedures, etc) that come along with any
'growing company. It's important to not get hung up on what's wrong, buttofocuson
what is happening that is right and the progress in actions (not just words) that support
that. With this growthisan opportunity to define the future and the role you playinit.
That mindset is rewarded at Perficient.

headline: Great work environment, few interesting projects
pros:
- Amazing benefits.
- Highly talented people.
- Friendly work environment, friendly management.
- Company strives to improve itself and acts on internal criticism.
- Accessibility to awesome technologies and insider information.
cons:
- Most projects aren't exciting.
- Lots of technical dept and bureacracy.
- Your performance is largely valued on how well you write about it, not on it actually being great.
- Hard to transfer teams if your performance doesn't exceed expectations.
- Internal work tools are dated, cumbersome and lacking compared to those in the industry.
- Mixed messages when it comes to work-life balance: management stresses the importance of work-life balance and gives us the freedom to put life first, but in practice this generally means your performance can worsen compared to your peers which influences your career path there.
- HR responds slowly for most bureacratic requests.

headline: Opportunity depends on the project
pros:
- Great place to learn good software development practices.
- Experience a lot of good infrastructure from the codebase, knowledge documentation, and dev tools.
- Good perks with transportation, food, and discounts with other companies.
cons:
- Growth opportunity really depends on the project and manager.
- Can be blind-sided with strategic changes from upper management.
- Maintaining multiple products in deprecation mode is discouraging.

headline: Becoming a "Lifestyle"
pros:
- Treats employees (esp. Engineers) very well
- Great benefits, awesome offices and perks
- Really good teammates
cons:
- Too many people treating Google like a lifestyle instead of a business. Focused on the perks instead of building great products.
- Pay becoming less competitive in the market unless the stock continues going crazy
- Over-leveled executives and under-leveled engineers coming into Google for the last several years.

headline: A great place to be even if it's grown in size and complexity
pros: Amazing benefits, general culture of friendliness / kindness / collaboration. Not all orgs are like this, but the ones I've been in are generally filled with people that want to do the right thing for their teams and their people, which makes employees feel very supported and safe.
cons: Size - Google is so complex and huge now it's harder to get anything done efficiently if you're in a larger part of the organization. Internal mobility outside of your org and direct area of expertise can feel daunting.

headline: Good place to get experience, can be extremely toxic
pros: Good place to get experience working in a global company, a lot of really nice people, salary is good
cons: Can be extremely toxic and political. By politics I mean how a lot of so-called people managers play power games that result in poor morale and inefficiency among "lower level people" (I heard this phrase directly from one of those managers).

headline: Great Brand Name and Benefits, ALOT OF CONS to consider
pros:
-Great benefits and insurance coverage, it's like no other!
-Most recognised brand name in the world.
-Alot of resources for you to leverage if you take the initiative
cons:
-Company is a massive machine so decision making and change has a massive drag, you will feel like a tiny cog in the machine
-Google down-levels you and you will feel short changed as performance review and promotion is biased
-Company stresses about DEI, pressures recruiters about diversity but does not do anything about inclusion
-Discriminatory practices around rewards and recognition
-No transparency with performance reviews and promotion
-It's very political
-Ill experienced managers who gaslights you

Google offers the best benefits among the top tech companies.
cons: Improve pay, it's not as good compared to the market as it was a few years ago.

headline: A large company with increasing hierarchy, but still amazing benefits.
pros:
Work culture (ie values, priorities, performance reviews, remote work) is largely determined at the organization / Director level now. People in different organizations can have vastly different experiences, and it's valuable to get to know your future coworkers to have a better understanding of the work environment, expectations, and teams you'd be collaborating closely with.

Teams aim to be strategic, highly efficient, and action-oriented.

There are tons of different active interest groups to participate in and meet people across the company. Great office spaces, amazing food, and exposure to lots of ideas.
cons: Roles can be very specialized, and mobility between job ladders / roles is more difficult than you may think (ie switching from UX Design to Product Manager). You would need to gain relevant experience in your current role with a 120% project, or have the relevant previous experience to interview as if you were an external candidate.

headline: Still awesome
pros: I've been here for five years now, and this place is still the best engineering environment that I have been a part of in my 15-year career. Code quality and automated testing is taken seriously. Code reviews are often rigorous and provide an amazing learning opportunity. You can have language experts review your code!
cons:
As stated elsewhere, there is enormous complexity. Google is a very large company, and unfortunately nothing is simple. Getting something done, something that doesn't seem especially difficult, can take longer than it should. 

Asynchronous workflows are the bane of my existence. You are always managing multiple work-streams: one is blocked on review, another is blocked on release, etc. It's annoying that I can't just "do things" as easily. But when the stuff is finally done it feels pretty great.

headline: Google Recruiting
author_position: Senior Technical Recruiter Or Recruiting Manager
pros: Google has incredible resources for learning high-tech and managing teams. There is outstanding onboarding, process documentation, and shadowing for new joiners. Google also has a strong work-life balance, anchoring meetings to midday to respect national timezones. The community of individuals is top-notch- amazingly smart, driven, and courteous colleagues.
cons: Given the scale of the operation, it's very hard to create change. The best opportunities and problems are often "gifted" down from managers to select individuals who are on fast promotion trajectories. Challenges are often framed so positively, it can feel impossible to ask the "real question," criticize efforts, or swim upstream. I saw individuals sent a strong message with their ratings for challenging the status quo. At times, this can feel toxic and insurmountable. The key here is aligning to strong managers who are transparent and supportive so you can get tapped for meaningful work, find a safe space for challenging assumptions, and get buy-in for your ideas.

headline: Best place to work at
pros:
Google is one of the best employers in the world by far. Here I do not want to talk about the perks, the salary or even the offices. Those have been written and talked about over and over again. But I would like to stress the culture and the people in this amazing company. 

Google strives to be a place for everyone, where everybody could bring their best selves. No matter who you are, what your gender is, what your background, color, ethnicity is, Google welcomes every single employee with open arms. The most important factor in Google teams is the issue of psychological safety. This means that as an individual, I should not be afraid to raise my voice about my opinions and fear for retaliation, humiliation or discrimination. Google believes that great organisations/companies can only strive with open mind and collaboration and in order to have everyone bring their best ideas there should be psychological safety. Which unfortunately, is not the issue for most of the companies in the world.

The other thing I would like to talk about is the quality of the employees. I kid you not, every single employee feels like they are smarter than you. When you first come to the company you get this huge imposter syndrome because you think you're a hiring mistake, but then you talk to other people and realise that everyone feels the same because of the smarts level around you. Thinking about it retrospectively I believe that this is an amazing feeling, a feeling that pushes you to be better and bring your best.
cons:
Honestly, the first and the major con I can think of is that once you start working for a company like Google it is very difficult to spread your wings and fly away to an other company because Google is incomparably better than others.

An other con might be the slow progression of career steps. Google is a huge employer with more than 150k employees around the world. This sometimes makes internal mobility and career progression slower or harder.

headline: The golden cage remains comfortable if inconveniently located
pros: Well compensated & nice offices when they're open
cons: The post-pandemic location strategy is locked to hubs with high cost of living and poor quality of life. Google seems more concerned with justifying their real estate purchases and operating in tax havens, rather than letting their ageing workforce move to cities and countries that better meet their evolving needs. It was irritating before Covid, now it's unjustifiable given what we've all achieved during 2 years of remote working.

headline: Your experience really depends on the team
pros:
- Perks (free food, discounts on goods, massage points, gym, laundry, tons of stuff I'm forgetting)
- Health benefits. I'm on the PPO, which allows OON care. There's also more or less unlimited sick days and disability leave
- Decent accommodations for my disability. Can't speak too well to other people's disability accommodations, but it does look like they're trying
- All my coworkers respect my pronouns (they/them)
- Work/life balance is what you make of it. You have flexible hours and can come in more or less whenever you want. Still, most people work 50-60 hours. It's possible to do 40, but don't expect to get promoted. Nominally, work/life balance is encouraged, but secretly, it really isn't.
cons: If you're on a big team, the bureaucracy is enormous. Good luck getting anything done when you have a billion approval processes to go through. Also the organization structure is incredibly unstable. You will have a new manager every 1-3 years even if you stay on the same team just from reorgs.

headline: Avoid
pros: Very smart colleagues and interesting work.
cons: Long hours and intense work environment -- expect to be on call 24/7. Culture has become truly toxic, especially in Legal / Public Policy, due to systemic bad hiring and promotion decisions: "Snake pit" is the phrase that best describes the culture now. Many employees are unhappy, yet stay because of unbeatable compensation packages. Company and its leadership prioritize financial performance above all else -- anyone who questions leadership or its values is systematically shown the door. Google's original "values" are long gone. Good place to go if your only goal is to maximize compensation.

headline: 90% a utopia...10% dystopia
pros:
+ managers seem to work hard to find the right level of comfort / challenge
+ definitely some interesting perspectives
+ have the tools to do your job
+ lots of autonomy
cons:
- PMs act like little CEOs. They take a lot of ownership of their project and can make others feel like they're working in an agency
- process, process, process
- the loud researchers are highly opinionated
- easy to trick yourself into working longer/harder
- VERY performance oriented, which works well because most people seem like they enjoyed getting straight As their entire lives (this kind of sucks if you like, uh, taking it easy and not being stressed)
- people may have very different backgrounds, but they have similar ways of thinking about problems, which I'm not sure ultimately helps the people using the products.

headline: A parallel reality for tech, as long as you can handle the politics
pros:
- Amazing in-house infrastructure that you can learn a lot from
- Very talented colleagues
- Plenty of ownership over what you do (compared to companies that aggressively "follow the market")
cons:
- Becoming more and more opaque (esp. upper management), openly destroying the transparent and communicative culture that used to predominate
- Lots of incentives to rush things in time for perf/promotion cycles since management mostly cares about new shiny launches (just see how little users trust Google at this point to keep their products alive or do good customer service)
- Massive company = lots of managers and arbitrary bureaucratic power. It's up to luck whether you can escape internal politics and have a good experience or get stuck in a toxic team
- Very very political environment which can be really draining
- Even in Europe, American views on identity and race trump all (if you're white, it's irrelevant if you came from a poor family in a post-soviet country, you need to check your privilege)

headline: Good place to work. Beware of drinking the kool-aid though!
pros:
Amazing colleagues
Great learning
You can tell your friends you work there & they'll be in awe
Good internal mobility - with caveats
cons:
Compensation & levelling are negotiated at hire. If you get down-levelled at hire then there is no easy way out - welcome to multiple years of career stalling
Perf process is opaque and in non-tech orgs, it's very manager dependent.
If you work there long enough, be prepared to find out that new people are being hired with less experience, greater compensation and better roles/titles/levels than you.
Internal mobility - opportunities abound but parity with market sucks!
Oh, and regardless of which team you are in, learn to play the political game or lose

headline: 1yo SWE@Google
pros:
- Best (not perfect) working culture I've ever had. Very warm and helpful environment makes me wonder new things for the new day. 
- The company tries to create/sustain an inclusive working environment
- Everything is in big scale, which is not an opportunity that you can get in relatively small companies.
- Great learning opportunity if you're willing to.
- Compensation
cons:
- Steep learning curve while on-boarding due to google specific technologies
- Some tech stack are very specific to google and thus your knowledge on those might lose value outside of google.
- Inter time-zone communication is sometimes difficult if you have some time difference to the US. I have to admit google is somewhat US centric company.

headline: Messy, not in a good way
pros: Smart, talented people to learn from.
cons:
The org did not scale well. No clear structure, vision or processes. Had to keep scrambling for resources that never came (head count, budget) with instructions often changing and no one owning the process. Some pillars are not properly budgeted = represented within product teams (e.g. data science, content design, operations). Overall the company tends to lean too much on individual initiatives (not scalable or repeatable) over defining how things should be done and investing in the appropriate resources.
Performance evaluations rewards employees mainly on visibility forcing one to focus on it all the time. Being dependant on peer reviews for your rating or promo had a negative effect of 'not wanting to rock the boat'.

headline: Absolutely the best place to work
pros: Of course, the obvious work-life balance, the office perks, and so forth are there, but the real pros would be working alongside very smart individuals that can provide professional growth during your career at Google.
cons: It's very protected (against the outside elements like the economy), and very comfortable. After several years, your stock options will be so large that you will not want to leave the company to take on new challenges. Job security is great but if you are not too aggressive about your career, you can get complacent.

headline: Great Benefits Cover Corporate Corruption
author_position: Associate Account Strategist, Global Customer Services
pros: The benefits of Google are undeniable - health care coverage, time off, food, the amazing people you encounter, you name it.
cons: The biggest issue I had with Google (and the main reason I left the company) was the lack of transparency they had in the promotion process and moving laterally across the company. As a company that boasts about transparency...this was pretty embarrassing. If you join the company in say, sales, it's exceptionally challenging to move to another section of the company (ex: marketing). My recruiter also lied and told me I could transfer offices after a year. He didn't mention I'd have to find a new position in order to do so.

headline: New Managers are problematic
pros:
1.The fellow engineers and culture of helping each other is awesome.

2. You will love the tech-stack, technology, coding environment and engineering culture.

3. The learning support website is awesome.
cons: Earlier in Google, the engineer@L6 used to become Manager and they were awesome. But now since the number of higher intake, more managers are needed and the number of L6 is less, So Google started hiring from service companies. These new managers are nuisance. Just avoid any team which has got such manager. Join a team only if the Manager is a veteran engineer in Google and an engineer, rather than a direct hire at L6 level.

headline: Fantastic culture and mission
pros:
- The people is what makes this company great. Everyone is extremely intelligent, but very humble and kind. Google really does attract the best people (the genuinely good ones, school prestige doesn’t matter here).
- Strong mission to care about the users/customers, that they constantly emphasize
- Strong, genuine emphasis on diversity and psychological safety in the workplace because they really do understand the power of both. It’s unlike many companies who do it for image.
- Every org has strong leadership that drives and executes its strategy, so the business will definitely be sustained for a long time (no worries about unemployment or stagnation)
cons:
- Could be more transparent about compensation
- Frustrating lack of communication + unstable plans about return to office

headline: Great Compensation, Terrible Aesthetic
pros: Google's highly structured algorithmic compensation planning and promotion system has helped me climb the individual contributor ladder quickly, after languishing in junior roles at startups for several years. The benefits package is to die for, especially as a transgender woman attempting to start a family.
cons:
Google has no aesthetic sensibility whatsoever. Google's rigorous focus on metrics means that anything that can be easily measured is optimized for, and anything that is difficult to measure is systematically neglected. Many important aspects of product design and software engineering exist in this subjective realm, and are impossible to turn our focus upon without being punished by the performance review process.

Many of Google's important internal tools, including such essentials as source control and front-end frameworks, are hilariously antiquated. Google is systemically allergic to third-party dependencies and essentially out of conversation with the open source community. Internally, many open source best practices are regarded with open hostility.

Turnover is very high, and org charts are very deep. Conversations with decision-makers are filtered through many layers of management, resulting in game-of-telephone miscommunication and planning processes which move slower than market conditions. Short-term thinking is systemically encouraged by itinerant managers and ICs eager to achieve promotion quickly and move on to their next team.

Nevertheless, meaningful work is possible for ICs who are steel-nerved and internally motivated.

headline: A company that requires a lot from you, but gives you a lot too!
pros:
- People: the main pros in Google are definitely the people, open minded and driven folks from whom you can learn on a daily basis 
- Businesses you work with: based on your role you have the opportunity to work with start ups, unicorn, fast growing companies or large established companies across all the verticals
- Internal relocation: Google is part of Alphabet which allows you to explore multiple options across different businesses based on what you might be interested mostly in
- Perks
cons:
- Size of the company: Google is not anymore what was used to be 10years ago hence career progression might be slower which for high ambitious people could considered a limitation
- Middle Management: many professionals became managers based on the tenure in the company hence some of them might be struggling of being people managers and/or their knowledge of the business might be limited (considering that advertising and technology are going at a fast speed), hence the type of support and empowerment top down sometimes does not meet the expectations.

cons: Combination of hard to fire people and sustained high growth (20-30% YoY increase in revenue/profits leads to similar clip for hiring) leads to rushed decisions to bring people on board, but reluctance to let those go who aren't a good fit. Hard to maintain culture when growing so fast, adds a lot of bureaucracy.

headline: Declining - very quickly
pros:
Benefits
Compensation (especially at higher levels)
Flexibility
cons: Google Cloud is rapidly cutting costs and is turning GCP into Oracle. Only a few years left, at best. Your happiness in role is a largely due to your management chain. Most managers at Google are good, but most directors+ are from consulting companies. Ex-consultant directors/VPs are ruining what it has been like at Google. The $ ship has sailed, but there may be a few more years here. Get in, get it on your resume, sell as much stock as you can, and leave.

Rising COVID-19 lockdowns are spreading across South Vietnam’s manufacturing heartland, with an extended lockdown drastically cutting factory production and paralyzing parts of the supply chain, forwarders operating in the region say.
Cases of the highly infectious Delta variant are rising at an average rate of 3,000 per day, SEKO Logistics reported Tuesday. Ho Chi Minh City, center of the south’s largest manufacturing base in the Southern Key Economic Zone that has been locked down since July 9, has extended restrictions for another month to Sept. 15.

headline: Nice work balance and pay
pros: At Google, the Software Engineers are the best paid employees in the company, on a typical salary of more than $103,000. Even their software interns are some of the highest paid in technology, earning more than $82,000. This could nearly double once they climb to the dizzying heights of Senior Software Engineer level, at $139,000.
cons: There is an expectation that you will actively continue to educate yourself and expand your knowledge as a Google employee. You are encouraged to commit to self-improvement as well as expanding your skills. Some might see this as an imposition on their time, but it is simply part of life in today’s ever-changing work environment – especially in technology – and many businesses have adopted a similar culture.

headline: The grass is always greener
pros:
Excellent Compensation
Really Great Perks
Working with some of the best and brightest
Access to cutting edge technology
Prestige
cons:
Despite paying lip service to the importance of diversity, your success or failure at Google all comes down to who you boss is. The way that performance in sales roles is judged heavily favors neurotypical people in that you are expected to have immediate recall and be able to task switch constantly. 

This is incredibly difficult for people with ADHD and despite going to HR and opening conversations with my manager I was managed out, despite consistently hitting all of my sales goals.

There has also been a marked cultural shift away from the original core tenants. This comes with the type of growth they have experienced but it can be disheartening to see the values the company used to stand for be cast aside in the pursuit of ever increasing revenue goals.

headline: Tons of great people but upward mobility is a challenge; very hierarchical with respect to Engineering levels

cons: Upward mobility is a challenge; people on the Eng Manager ladder are overqualified and all competing for a small set of growth opportunities; you're not promoted until you've demonstrated sustained, next-level competence but you can't demonstrate next-level competence because they put you in a box based on your current level, preventing you from accessing such opportunities; your manager has to create a next-level opportunity for you to do so; so you're somewhat beholden to your manager to progress; very hierarchical with respect to Engineering levels; they mean more than you might imagine (especially if you've not worked for Big Tech companies before; down-leveling for experienced hires is the norm

headline: Still good, but has become a big company.
pros: Hiring & people philosophy. Hire very selectively to get very good people, then pay & treat them well to keep them.
cons:
Difficult to find a good role in the company.
- 75%+ (90%?) of projects are worthless/pointless & destined to go nowhere. On these projects, you can lead a team & the culture is typically good - but your work will never have a real impact.
- At most 25% of projects (probably less) have any chance of having much impact. On those projects, its very difficult to get a role as more than a cog. Also, those teams can afford to (and tend to) have a crappier culture & push people much harder because people want to work on them.
Most people end up working on things they aren't really interested in, or in roles they wouldn't take or stay-in at other companies.
Management quality varies *a lot*. I've seen some managers who were good at their job and also decent human beings. I've seen some that absolutely didn't deserve their roles, and/or that were vey sleazy. Google will basically always consider your manager to be correct in any dispute/disagreement with you, so a bad/sleazy manager can be very bad for your career at G.

headline: Senior management cares only about creating good appearance of a healthy company
pros:
- still lots of great & smart people to work with, but the numbers are dwindling
- *some* tech and dev infra is really cool and ahead of times
- company brand that still means a lot to many
cons:
Lots of great people are leaving and being replaced by people that are very junior, or with senior people with values that didn't use to be common at Google.

Senior management is often more interested in just creating an appearance of a happy and healthy company, rather than actually solving some hard problems.

A lot of technical debt that is increasingly hard to address due to the scale of the company.

In spite of increasingly making more and more money, the management invests less and less back into the company and its employees.

headline: Incredible benefits and compensation, great coworkers, difficult work
pros: If you are looking for a large company to work and grow comfortably in, this is the place to be. The benefits are everything you've heard and more, though work expectations are high. Almost all of my coworkers were high-performing diligent workers and the management was heavily hands-on.
cons: Performance review cycles and promotion can be cumbersome, and the general size of the company means bureaucracy and communication between departments is difficult. Internal divide between the treatment of contract workers and full-time workers causes friction, and the companies mission and direction are becoming increasingly corporate.

headline: All around great
pros:
- compensation
- benefits
- office perks
- products with billions of users
- public commitments to diversity, equity, inclusion, and the environment
cons:
- it's a large company now and has lost it's ability to move fast (product dependent)
- increased bureaucracy: getting anything of consequence implemented requires 10+ types of reviews (code, design, a11y, privacy, sre, logging, legal, QA, support, i18n, capacity, security, leadership), many of which have overburdened and slow reviewers
- senior staff and managers spend ~40% of the year doing performance review tasks in the background (self-assessments, peer feedback, calibration, promo committees)
- mostly use internal proprietary tech which comes with increased maintenance burden through technical mandates and deprecations

headline: Bad Promo Process and Mediocre Salary
pros: Google has an awesome company culture and perks. Culture: management is accessible, your voice can be heard at team meetings and even all-hands meetings, people respect you, and I always felt cared about as a person. Perks: I thoroughly enjoyed the free breakfast/lunch/dinner, baristas, gym, commuter bus, and subsidized massages.
cons:
Google has to make some serious changes to improve its performance management and promotion processes. Called "Perf", it's a twice a year process that managers and staff alike despise because it takes up enormous amounts of time and results in questionable promotion decisions. 

In Finance, approximately 10% of the team can get promoted in any given Perf cycle and there are only two per year. I recommend learning about Google's internal level system during the hiring process and asking what level your role is before you accept the job offer. Talk to a friend or contact and see if the leveling of your role is reasonable to start with. I was hired at too low of a level and then slow (3 years) to reach my first promotion. 

Finance Levels at Google (rough work experience required):

L3 Financial Analyst (1-2 years)
L4 Financial Analyst (2-4 years)
L5 Senior Financial Analyst (4-6 years)
L6 Finance Manager (6-8 years)
L7 & L7.5 Senior Finance Manager (8+)
L8 Finance Director (12+)

L5 is the terminal level for many Finance employees. It's extremely difficult to get into management. L6 and above are very political promotions. For promotions at levels 3-5, they are largely time-based (2 years on average for L3/L4, 3 years for L5). Super strong performers do not get promoted more quickly, contrary to what Google claims. 

While total compensation (salary + 15% bonus + equity) is often competitive, the salary component is quite low and makes it hard to afford the SF Bay Area cost of living, especially in your first year before you get a bonus and before any of your equity vests.

headline: One year at Google review
pros:
Incredible on-site benefits

Heavy investment into diversity equity and inclusion.

Great work life balance and ability to shut work off to focus on your family. Great support across the organization for this.
cons:
Each of the leaders operates in their own silo, this causes confusion, duplicate work, and no vision cross-organizationally.

There is a ton of red tape to get through to make even the smallest of change for the better.

The organization has a very anti sales culture.

There are some serious issues with the wage gap still at this organization between male and female workers.

headline: Great place to work. Cloud is becoming a different company.
pros:
Benefits
Collaborative atmosphere
Smart and driven colleges
Massive growth in Cloud and potential to shape.
cons:
The Google Cloud part of the company is turning more and more into a very traditional B2B Enterprise company as the workforce has been grown aggressively through external hires from Oracle, SAP and Microsoft. Google's culture is much less present there, with more emphasis on hirarchy, 'sales culture' and politics compared to Google's traditional very entrepreneurial, hands-on and 'engineering culture'.

Still a good place to work with collaborative, smart and friendly coworkers. Just not necessarily how you would expect Google to be.

headline: Amazing if not for a fatal flaw.
pros:
+) Extremely high compensation. When I switched to another big tech company, I actually ended up taking a small paycut despite getting a promotion.
+) Very flexible working hours (I had a coworker who worked four ten hour days and took Fridays off)
+) Excellent perks. Free food for three meals a day (of very good quality) plus snacks, and plenty of "teambuilding" events that are basically excuses to enjoy an afternoon off with coworkers.
+) A few years working at Google will make your resume and let you join pretty much any company you choose.
cons:
-) Extremely political. Google is all about bringing your whole self to work, so long as your whole self is progressive. There are a number of activists within the company who will protest at the drop of a hat. This may be a positive for some people, but anyone on the right, or even in the center of the political spectrum will have to bite their tongue to remain employed. 
-) Getting promoted within the company is a difficult ordeal, and the effort may not match the results.

headline: A Big Company that pretends it's a Startup
pros: Amazing tech, excellent benefits, a very generous employer. Salaries are not top of the line, but certainly high; office amenities are well documented; there are various budgets and stipends for training and learning; out of hours on-call times get (some) time off in lieu.
cons:
Many policies are enforced unevenly, the dismissal of various "troublemakers" have made the news and should be reviewed carefully. There is a significant amount of gaslighting and straight up dishonesty about policies, especially around topics where it is easy to be vague such as communications and confidentiality.

The positives above only apply to Engineering teams. Life is very different in Sales, I am told. 

While there are many claims about "we're a family" and "community" and so on, there is the usual strong disconnect between senior and exec management and the individual contributors at the coalface. This is expected in a huge company, but as it fails to admit that it is a huge company, it takes no steps to correct this.

headline: fun place to work at, fewer growth opportunities

headline: In crisis/decline
pros: Everything combined together.. the experience is still positive. Decent treatment, good benefits, interesting work, intelligent people to work with.
cons:
Constant inflows of new employees bringing bad work cultures with them. 
Corpspeak has been now successfully adopted by most management. 
Scale brings constant re-orgs.
Cant get anything quite right.
No longer empowered to own and do your job..you will now be playing pin pong with tickets between multiple teams. 
Constantly trying to escape being vendorized. Breaking down processes so they can be handed to vendors instead of done by employees.

headline: Interesting experience, but not what I expected or hoped for.
pros:
People.
General culture.

Couldn't tell you about the perks, because I joined during the pandemic, so there are no perks.
cons:
Pay isn't quite what it should be, though they claim it's "market rate". It's not.. Well below, but they figure they'll get someone since the app rate is so high.

If you join them, make sure you join actual Google, not wind up in some company they acquired that is going to take years to acclimate. You'll never get to experience actual Google life. I joined Google for the Google experience, and instead got the GoogleNotGoogle experience.

headline: Learning opportunity
pros: Really cool place to work, they've taken the time to make the office feel like a relaxed place to be in. Also, having Google on my CV has been invaluable - recruiters will always ask about it and so I feel it gives me a bit of an edge. I was always working on some really exciting, cutting edge projects and each day was varied with what I was working on. It's hard to get bored here.
cons: The work/life balance wasn't so good; it was very easy to find yourself working late 3-4 times a week. Most of my projects were lone-working so I didn't have much opportunity to make friends or learn from peers/management. There also wasn't much space for internal progression.

headline: krishna java
pros:
Free.
Fast and easy to edit.
No programming or database skills are required.
Ideal for a newbie who wants to build a website for the first time.
No software installation is required.
Integrated with Google apps.
The creator can access tools anywhere.
Creator has full control over page access and permission.
cons:
Limited functionality compared to other website builders.
Not really a good website for business - not enough customization.
Apps are only limited to Google apps only. ...
The site URL must begin with "sites.google.com/site/" which is too long for a website.

headline: the best company
pros: Human resource is known as “People Operations” at Google to make it sound more friendly. This department uses data to take a proactive approach to ensure the happiness of employees. For instance, when Google noticed a higher turnaround rate for women, they looked at data and noticed most were new mothers, which led to the implenetation of a generous maternity leave policy.
cons: Many modern American companies have developed a contrived culture of lingering at work. Ambitious, new or young talent may end up hanging out at the office outside of work hours, often working or learning. This can develop into peer pressure to spend a lot of time at the office. Apart from coffee shops and libraries, some places have “sleep pods” for that swift power nap to help you keep going for longer. The Toronto Office even has a crazy golf putting green on the roof!

headline: Best perks / tech of any company I've worked for, but decisions are now slow
pros: Can't beat the perks (international travel opportunities, education stipend, etc.) and the technical innovation you are surrounded by pretty much anywhere else; total comp pay is high but not as high as that of Facebook (still very solid though) and the things you can work on are more varied (Google is in so many industries).
cons: It can take a really long time for senior leaders to make a decision because it's such a big company and you are rewarded for steering the ship slowly and safely, not for risk-taking. Like any big company, it also has its own team and internal politics that result in building what someone wants (maybe for their own personal passion or career advancement) and not for what the customer might want or what's best for Google.

headline: Great place to work

headline: system engineer working at google
pros:
We're Social Beings. People need people. ...
We Need to Have Purpose. I think work provides an avenue to fulfill a purpose – or at least the feeling of it. ...
Feeling Productive is Good for the Soul. ...
To Maintain a Standard of Living. ...
We're Creative Beings.
cons:
Willpower. Gotta get jamming on this new project, but Netflix says you still have 4 episodes of Tiger King to watch...
Difficulty sticking to a routine. The order you do things at work is almost never the order you do things at home. It can be tough to mirror your schedule and processes once outside the office.
Missing important calls or pings. Oops, my phone was on do not disturb and I missed a meeting! Or my boss slacked me and asked to prioritize something else and now it’s 4:45pm ...
Calling UberEats anyways. You thought you were saving money, didn’t you? Blam-o! $20 minimum and a $5 fee for the higher rated Thai place. Should’ve remembered to buy bread …
Power naps. This could arguably could be in advantages … unless it accidentally lasts 45 minutes after your delivered double entree Thai lunch.
Boredom. Those office convos? Kinda missing Susan’s cat stories, eh? How long can you go without seeing another living human being?
Working slowly. Sometimes the office has an energy. Sometimes your home does not.
No second monitor. How did I ever work without two giant screens looming above me??? All 74 of my tabs are essential!
Iffy WiFi. At home or in a cafe, when the wifi start to spaz and you switch locations a couple of times but honestly spend more time parking and ordering a 6-shot mint mojito coffee with coconut milk and 16 grains of sugar than doing work.

headline: Simply the best
pros: There's a reason why the company is known as being the best of the best. Genuine interest in work/life balance; takes feedback from employees; no micro management; perks are the best of any employer. Free breakfast, lunch and dinner if you want it. Multiple professional baristas on site for expertly brewed coffee; snack and drinks cupboards on every floor in the office; gym and swimming pool and classes on site. Massages, even a hairdresser and post office and bank in the office! At the end of every year you get a salary review/increase and a stock refresh. Management and fellow employees are all unbelievably talented and wonderful colleagues who are keen to lift and support each other.
cons: Can be slow to get promoted and progress up the company. Upward mobility is hard.

headline: Prestigious, fascinating, great benefits but EXHAUSTING and poor work/life balance
pros: It's GOOGLE. Great benefits, probably the most stable OTE pay for a sales role EVER, perks galore, and the chance to develop yourself and shape your career path with the world's greatest resources.
cons: Despite the perks and the prestigious logo, work/life balance is poor. Google is filled to the brim with over-achievers always intent on promo or their next role. This, along with an INSATIABLE demand for growth, leads to unhealthy work/life balance. My teammates and I regularly burnout and get sick from exhaustion. Management knows about this and still lacks compassion. Instead of truly "seeing you," they say something like "working hard doesn't mean you are working smart." This sentiment hurts, especially when mgmt is constantly throwing you last-minute AIs and adding new OKRs/KPIs.

headline: Kind of manipulative
pros: Plenty of perks like food, health insurance, etc.
cons: It almost feels like a cult full of toxic positivity. The work culture is quite unhealthy - some people are in the office as early as 6 am and leave as late as 10 pm to hit their targets. Targets are often set at unattainable levels that require this kind of time commitment. They also emphasize “culture fit” in the hiring process, but if you start in sales and would like to move to something more gratifying that you would experience more success in, it’s nearly impossible. All that matters is how much money you make them.

headline: Great people and benefits, too much bureaucracy
pros:
- Colleagues are as a rule friendly, helpful, intelligent.
- Easy transfers between projects and orgs, many different and interesting problems to work on.
- Great office benefits, global presence makes travel + work easy. Good pay.
- Great work-life balance if you want it, little danger in getting managed out. Good (but slow) advancement opportunities as IC or EM if you want to work hard.
cons:
- So much process and bureaucracy. Most of it is well-intentioned but project planning and launch is very CYA
- Slow-moving by default. Everyone is capable of being very productive, but moving fast doesn't seem rewarded much more than moving slow.
- Giant company, no individual project gets much exec attention or moves the needle much on P&L

headline: Googleyness is real
pros:
Please note that I am working for Google Cloud which is a pretty independent unit within the greater Google.

- Very smart and creative but humble people, you won't find the brashness and blabla that are seen in corporate environmnets too often
- High level of trust, no micro-management, managers are subject matter experts and not just "managers
- Employees are entrusted with big responsibilities from an early point on and encouraged to take on projects that go beyond the usual scope of the core job 
- Possibility of taking on a 20% project which does not even need to be connected to core job
- Techy, data driven, nerdy, quirky culture
- Great technology + GCP is getting more and more successful particularly among startups/ tech companies
- Intriguing environment, just check things like "Talks at Google" on YouTube
- Great benefits, salary, stock options
cons:
- Google Cloud, particularly in the startup/ SMB segment feels a bit like startup itself which also means chaotic at times - Many processes aren't well defined
- Too many complex, self built tools 
- Google is quite insistent on hiring in Dublin, particularly in Cloud SMB. This will need to change since Dublin is an objectively less attractive city than say Amsterdam or Berlin

headline: Amazing culture, enablement
pros: Legendary benefits, as well known in the media. It's true. There is a great work atmosphere in the campus. The work-life balance is amazing as well - no one bothers you after 5pm or on weekends. There is nothing I could say bad about Google culture.
cons: The situation seems a bit too relaxed at times. There are people who seem too comfortable in their roles. Several orgs within Google could use some hunger/fire in what they do. Senior management is not impressive. Colleagues are.

- Move up or move out culture

headline: Prepare to be pampered
pros:
1. Work with some of the very smartest people in the industry.
2. Perks on perks, endless perks, you won't even be able to find them all on the public internet, prepare to be pampered daily.
3. Some of the coolest tech offices in the world. And you can visit any of them at any time if you happen to be stopping by! (Not right now because of COVID, obviously)
4. Quite possibly the best internal tools in FAANG.
5. Stock is a rocketship right now.
6. Get first-hand insight on some really cool and cutting-edge projects. Although unfortunately, you won't always be allowed to talk about them externally.
7. On average, great WLB (30-40 hrs/wk). But as with any company, it's entirely team-dependent, so do your research before joining a team!
cons:
1. Pay is not as crazy as it was, say in 2010. (But still among the top in the industry)
2. Still some uncertainty around WFH policy.
3. Some of the projects are really cool but might never see the light of day. Just how big tech is though, sometimes.

headline: If the guy who threatened my job could get promoted, this is not the place where I want to work.
pros:
The pay was decent for the bay.
Lots of amazing people, got to meet and see all kinds of cool people. 
Got to travel
Occasional perks made some things nicer, but they were often ephemeral. 
FTE status for extra perks sometimes.
cons:
Too much to complain about. I deleted a lot that would have probably identified me. 

My first manager threatened my job in a private meeting. Told me other managers were gossiping about me. He told me my job was in danger if I kept submitting negative feedback about his (eventually proven to be bad) idea. I communicated that the expectations set when I started were being abandoned. I told him how my last job they hired me away from stuck to their expectations at least, and he told me to go back to my old job. 

Another manager, in a small meeting of himself and some ITRs did it to a group of people once too. "Remember, we're the ones who sign your conversion papers". I didn't feel secure and was often anxious around management, because I never knew who was gossiping about me and who wasn't. 

How would you react to this kind of hostility? I was too afraid to report him, so I watched him get promoted away from his mistakes and failed responsibilities. I was mentorless, directionless, and the guy who I thought was looking out for me was just looking out for himself. 

This kind of trash happened more than once, and the managers should be ashamed of themselves for starting cliques and discouraging honest, candid feedback. 

This program was not googly, and this is not the only reason.

headline: Everything you'd expect from Google
