headline: Great yet big company
pros: The company culture is great and employees are taken care of nicely. Compensation is high. The internal development infrastructure is awesome!
cons: The company is now very big with a lot of momentum. Google hasn't spent enough effort to ensure they are keeping up with smaller competitors. Sometimes decisions are made a certain way simply because it is easier not because it is the best way forward. In the system infrastructure team, it is hard to make impact because of the massive change it takes to alter things even slightly.

headline: brilliant and horrendous at the same time
pros: great people, smart, friendly, helpful, ambitious, motivated colleagues, very interesting work, superb compensation and general employee package.
cons:
long serving leadership (loads of people who’ve been there for 14+ years) have lost sight of the outside world and have a very over blown sense of their own importance! 
the company is absolute chaos, everything overlaps, no one is sure who does what, everyone competes hard to be seen as the winner
it’s very siloed, all the different bits of google run as pretty separate companies so for anyone or team in roles that have to deal with more than one of the engineering groups, it is very hard to get them to work together.

headline: Avoid gTech - It's a scam
pros: Overall, Google is a nice place to work. There's a high concentration of smart people and loads of interesting things going on.
cons:
Avoid 'gTech' at all costs, especially as an engineer.. It's a highly political and dysfunctional org where everything is about "helping" customers or sales (never with anything interesting though) and making up bs metrics about what you've done. 

They'll lure you in with all the benefits of working at Google and the promise to work on exciting things. Don't let them fool you, the actual work is mind numbing and the culture is terrible. gTech is easily the worst place to be in Google and you'll regret joining within a year. Attrition is very high and internal transfers to a decent org are hard, so most people leave pretty soon.

headline: Bleh
pros: - Major props for getting Google on your resume
cons:
- Pay is really poor compared to counterparts
- wayyy too many “important people”. It’s hard to get things done because you’re too busy managing internal stakeholders. Everybody wants to feel important
- Perf has become an “allocation”. People who’re deserving don’t get promoted because there’s a limited amount and those who do get promoted do so because they’re “visible”, primarily because of visibility not because of great work. Visibility is important of course but when that’s the primary judge of great work....

headline: Great pay, nice people, a little boring
pros: Management is nice. There are very few bad apples and most people who work there are pretty smart. The engineering culture is solid. You can move around fairly easily. Promotion (at least at the basic levels) is fair.
cons: The job is a little boring. A lot of what made it famous early on -- 20% time, for instance, and real transparency from leadership, to name two such things -- have withered away as the company has grown to its current global status. It's a big company with a lot of bureaucracy. There's a lot of red tape and approvals to go through nowadays. No one at Google today is creating the next Gmail in their free time.

headline: Rushed out the Door
pros: Free food, nice offices, resources for mental health that you'll probably need after working there for a while.
cons:
In my experience the focus has been on rushing something out the door. Not necessarily something good, or something completely functional (even for the minimal features in the MVP), just something. Frequently software is rushed, testing is skimped on, and higher up engineers are unwilling to learn modern software development practices to improve software performance, reliability, developer experience, and user experience.

If you do not like to cut corners, do not work at Google. After spending 4 years here, being told by 3 managers that I care too much about my work and spend too much time making it right (while simultaneously being dinged on perf for it being 'not right enough'), and witnessing Google's willingness to protect sexual abusers and the bottom line over its purported values, the veneer of friendliness seems very disingenuous.

headline: Google Shopping/Express - Difficult experience at best
pros: Lots of perks, such as food, shuttle, personal and professional development classes. Good, smart, hard-working peers.
cons:
Google Shopping (formerly Express) was quite the hot mess, essentially an immature, messy start-up despite being a part of the larger Alphabet family. No clear vision or direction, more like 'let's throw stuff on the wall and see what sticks.'

Very frustrating experience to be a part of -- unrealistic work loads on the shoulders of a few, constant clashing between different groups that were supposed to be collaborative and working towards the same goal (i.e. the customer). Very hard to make data-driven decisions for the customer with constant bullying and micro-aggressions from the Category Management team to push their specific agenda (i.e. revenue goals and merchant favoritism).

A constant revolving door of contractors who did the majority of the work, who were under constant pressure, overworked, and under-appreciated and under-valued. Direct management of such contractors couldn't even be bothered to manage, engage, or acknowledge these extended workforce folks.

headline: Good gig, tough advancement for women
pros: The benefits are excellent and colleagues are smart and kind. Competitive pay. Good parental leave. Access to a lot of training resources.
cons: It is hard to advance as a woman, especially if you are not an engineer or a product manager. HR does not deal with investigations in a transparent way. It’s a boy’s club and can be emotionally exhausting. It’s very hard to get promoted, but it’s not a bad place to spend a few years. Unfair things happen all the time. If you can emotionally disengage, you can have a good personal life.

headline: Not what they claim
pros: Google is a great place to work for many reasons.
cons:
That being said- the start-up ideology is completely dead there. There is very little room for moving quickly, and everything has to be reviewed by a number of people before submission. I often found myself wondering: "Why hire 'the best' if you're just going to make them review each other's code forever?" 

Wrote more emails and did more code reviews than I ever got to write any code.

headline: Great place to grow and learn steadily in your middle to late career
pros: Benefits and perks are industry-leading, and work culture is very conducive to separating work and life. I feel supported by the policies and management expectations that are put in place to encourage wellness, honest feedback, and time off when necessary. The average tenure of a Googler seems longer than the average big-tech (ex-FB), and I think that's due to the long-term mobility you can find here - whether it's across business units, movement to XFN teams, and even to new markets/offices.
cons: Very large and ever-growing company creates a lot of product and workstream silos, potential for overlap, and definitely an incredibly heavy consensus-driven culture. Working here teaches you to collaborate and manage internal stakeholders, but this comes at the expense (sometimes) of moving quickly and feeling autonomous.

headline: Great work atmosphere, slowly turning to the dark side.

headline: Great career first steps
pros:
- Great colleagues (for the most part) - interesting people who genuinely want to help and support one another.
- Great learning opportunities as you can virtually sign up to learn anything internally as Google has many different teams/orgs/functions.
cons: Given the size of the company, it might be tough to tie your work to the impact you are making. If "what" you do matters and if you are not passionate about advertising, it can be tough to grow further. Additionally, each team/org has their drawback, whether it is an excessive focus on metrics/target, or how you need to manage upward to get further in the corporate ladder (but one can argue that you need that skill anywhere in life).

headline: Long Term Lookback
pros: Excellent meals. Generally a great work environment. Superb internal tools. Folks are nice. Very low pressure environment.
cons:
Lots of talent there, but not always clear what to work on. Warehouses full of shelf-ware. Many half baked projects start and are vaporized when they lead nowhere. This is a good strategy for Google - as a monopoly they the can start a 1000 projects - if a couple turn out well they write the others off - as their giant cash machine covers all costs.

One beef; it's harder being older there. Explicit age-ism was very rare, but there was a strong strain of "let's celebrate youth" - the famous "take your parents to work day". Once in a while I was on the receiving side of some condescending nonsense as an "unwoke" ancient. It's precious snowflake central - nice kids - but they've no clue on how the rest of the working world works.

headline: Top Tier Company
pros: My favorite thing about working at Google is the people you work alongside. Everyone I have ever worked with at Google is an intelligent, hard working, and overall kind person. The work environment is also fast paced, ambiguous, innovative and rewarding. The company has a great culture overall and a lot of opportunity for learning and growth.
cons: It can be difficult to land a role in your location of preference due to high competition and focus on specific hub offices. In addition, job mobility can be harder when you are in business and non-Eng roles. Most positions are also located in expensive cities which may not work as well for people further in their career with greater preference and limitation on where they are willing to live.

headline: Loads of Commitment for Slightly Above-Average Pay
pros:
Above-Average Pay
Good People for the most part
High-quality Ad Products to sell (relative to competitors)
Solid 401k match and benefits
Global work community
Indirectly supports Alphabet's attempts to solve existential human challenges
cons:
Below average vacation days (inconsistent depending on country)
Wolf-in-sheep's clothing managerial styles / psychological tactics
Undeniable workaholic-culture, despite internal rhetoric to the contrary
"if it ain't completely broke, don't fix it" mentality with internal/external products
Under-staffed (at least in sales), resulting in excessively high client ratios
Under-resourced, creating productivity and scoping dilemmas
Advancement can be impossible if you are on the wrong team, at the wrong level, with the wrong manager

headline: Thankful for the experience, but not my cup of tea
pros:
-Lots of opportunities to change teams and roles
-Lots of company perks
-Overall appreciated the experience of working at Google, but would not go back by choice.
cons:
-Too much bureaucracy slowed down the decision making process, and made it difficult to do impactful work in a timely manner. 
-Management lacked inspiring vision for the team. 
-Culture of entitlement was demotivating. 
-Felt like working at a massive company that never effectively scaled it's startup processes.

headline: Awesome benefits, very entitled colleagues, not always the greatest culture
pros: Google treats it's people well. While you're working at google, you can trust that your benefits are nearly as good as they get, and your salary is probably about 80% as good as it gets.
cons: People who are fresh out of college, or maybe have been at Google too long, forget what other jobs in the field are like. The reference for comparison can be very skewed. At the same time, management can talk a big game about the culture that google has, but rarely lives up to the promises of transparency, and innovative thinking, etc. But it's such a big company, I'm sure this is all department by department, team by team.

headline: Get in, boost your CV, get out. Treat it as 6th year of studies.
pros: You get 3x more attention from recruiters. Salary in top 10% of employers. Free food.
cons: Extreme competition among engineers (expect being compared with people doing overtime to get promoted). Substandard designers, managers are just promoted engineers (so "manage yourself, I want to code"), custom tech for everything (so most of stuff you learn there you will never use again). Also you feel like playing a game: rules are highly artificial, people are "mastering strategies" to get ahead, nobody really cares about product. When you get in, learn the rules from someone who works there for 4+ years, and don't trust common sense.

headline: Do not join Google in this role
pros: -everything related to Google and not related to this role or the GCS org
cons:
Summary: it's not what it used to be anymore

-calling client's that don't want to talk to you and convincing them to do things that are often not needed for them but for Google to generate more money
-learning curve flattens extremley after 3-6 months. After that, just a very well paid call-center job
-no clear career/growth path. Google keeps enforcing level (promo) requirements that force you to do a job that could be done by a computer for 2 years. 2 years ago, you would only have to do that for one quarter. Back in the old days, you would do 20% projects with other teams to get out of GCS. But this becomes harder and harder as most people know how terrible the GCS Org/Job is and simply leave after a short time. It's also very hard to learn any transferable skills as all you do is call people and convince them to stuff (no brain power needed) 
-higher management in central Europe does not have a clear strategy. Feels more like they try to push their own promo as hard as possible. Also, they block any rotation that would help you to get out of GCS to more interesting roles
-Higher management in central Europe always says stuff like "we put you and your career first" - which only applies to the sales roles that almost no one wants to do for a long period of time 
-The level you will be joining on (l2) in GCS is so low that you can't even change to (almost) any other department before a promotion. Even after a promotion, your level is often too low. You are stuck in this role for 2 years + 1-2 years on the next level before you can do anything interesting 
-A location that almost no one likes. That's why they hire local irish people for higher management to enforce the location

Google provides incredible benefits and free resources for employees to learn relevant skills and subject areas that you can use to develop your current role or lead to a new one. I never feel like I run out of things to learn and explore within Google.
cons: Like all large corporations, it can feel quite bureaucratic and opaque when it comes to certain things, namely HR-related. That said, there are always ways to find answers to your questions in help center pages or a person at Google who can help.

headline: Great package, smart colleagues
pros:
* Great salary and bonuses
* Smart colleagues
* Good perks in the office (free food, gym, ...)
* Relative independence towards the hours of work, no micro-management
cons:
* Career progression is slow and gets slower as the number of employees gets higher (e.g. a few years ago, a SWE was expected to ramp-up to L5, while it would be L4 now); also, it could me smarter to move to Facebook/Amazon/... and come back to get a higher level
* Bureaucracy
* Poor independence regarding the projects (ton of reviews, etc.)
* Too much focus on inclusion / following the trends (e.g. Black Live Matters, etc.) rather than on the products (i.e. it became a highly political organisation)

This approach leads to burnout and some drama within teams.

headline: interesting preschool environment, typical lack of appreciation for educators
pros:
- work at a tech company and enjoy most of the benefits (if you can work It into your schedule)
- freedom in day to day work (*very team dependent)
- health insurance
cons:
- very low pay for the area - my recruiter literally told me my offer was considered "below a livable wage in the bay area", however I also had no room to negotiate based on experience ..lesson learned!
- unfair / biased hiring practices - theres at least one lawsuit in recent years alleging unequal pay between male and female teachers. I can confirm I knew of at least 1 male teacher who was hired as a level II when every female teacher I knew had been told by their recruiter they *must* start as a level I regardless of education or experience. I knew of at least one peer with a Masters who had to start as a level I - $16/hr. I am confident the male teacher did not have the same level of experience.
- unfair promotions - all about who you are friends with. if your team is a sinking ship you will likely go down with them at performance time regardless of your own individual performance
- HIGH attrition due to all of the above. constantly understaffed and making huge crazy sacrifices to stay in ratio 
- used to give stock options at hire - took them away without telling the population. huge uproar when everyone found out, followed by walk out protest and calls for raising base pay based on market standards. told by google leadership "we know educators being underpaid is a problem, but Google is not going to focus on that right now"
- few growth opportunities - only 3 levels of teacher when I was there in 2017, otherwise like a handful of operations and leadership positions. 
- base pay is bad but promotion compensation was worse, a slap in the face. when I was promoted from a level I to level II teacher (the 2nd of 3 levels I could aspire to, remember) my raise was literally less than a dollar + a few stock thank god, and my manager actually acted like It was a big deal. I cant really blame her, knowing now how some companies manage promotions and $$ when It comes down to It, but that was just insulting..for the both of us. not unusual for educators, especially in preschool, but Google sets their own standard high and when a company is always preaching how "employee first" they are you kind of get to hold them accountable to it in practice.

headline: Great people, learned a lot.
pros:
* Lots of really smart people, I learned way more here than anywhere else I've worked.
* Great salaries and benefits; free food, gym, laundry, etc. If I wasn't married I might have just bought a van and lived in the parking lot.
* Work/life balance was pretty solid, culture was fantastic.
cons:
* Everything is about your promotions and job number. Promotion is notoriously fickle, the metrics-driven approach tends to create behavior that isn't ideal.
* Work is not terribly interesting unless you're you're 99.9% percentile type.
* Outside of the major offices you're not going to advance very much. This is more of a job for when you want to kick back and relax rather than be ambitious.

headline: Google is an amazing place to work for the people, the growth, scale, variety and perks!
pros:
-) The people (coworkers are smart & nice). 
-) The growth (you willl get invaluable development feedback from 360 degree reviews, that, if you are able to internalize and incorporate the feedback, will propel your career forward)
-) Variety. So many groups in one place, that when you're ready for your next career exploration, it will be easy and smooth. Google wants to be the last place you'll ever work.
-) Scale. If you want to have lots of users, in some cases billions, Google is a lot of fun and you are helping many people who use your product directly or indirectly. 
-) Free food and stocked "micro-kitchens" with snacks. And, the shuttles (okay, in 2020-21 this isn't a factor, but it will be when we all go back.)
Help the environment and make friends with neighbors, while riding a climate controlled bus with leather seats and friendly bus drivers, to work & back. If you can read in cars, you also will probably be able to get all your email done on the way to and from work, and the day is just about getting real work done.
cons: It is a large company, with over 100,000 employees, so there are often many people involved in any given project. You will need to be patient to work with stakeholders. Most teams have minimal politics so this goes smoothly. Things take longer than in a startup, but on the other hand, the scale of users, products, infrastructure is much greater.

headline: Foot In Door To Google
pros: You get to work with intelligent (socially and book smart) people constantly whether they are your customers or your coworkers. You don’t have to know Google Ads to start the role and they train you in the product very well. By a year in the role you’ll be in the 95% percentile of Google ads experts and you’ll have the opportunity to explore other roles at Google if you please. If you do well your pay goes through yearly refreshes and It can make a huge difference. You get to bring your whole self to work and that’s really cool.
cons: If you are joining the role from another company It is very vague if you will come into the role as an L2 (hourly) or L3 and that can make a big difference in compensation. People with 2-3 years of experience can make the same as a college grad and that can be frustrating. While pay has the potential to go up if you perform well, promotions can feel slow due to only 2 cycles a year which can limit you from going to roles that require certain levels. You will be challenged and need to have discipline, but it’s not a cutthroat environment in the slightest everyone helps everyone.

headline: Incredible growth
pros: Google cloud is growing rapidly, and that opens up growth opportunities constantly. There's an unbelievable innovation pace, new products/features being released all the time. The people at Google is really the best, there's a lot of great talent, and while Google needs to continue to improve the diversity, specially on management roles, I think the Google Cloud team is fairly diverse.
cons: There's a lot of change, and for some people this could be stressful, because there's a lot of adjustment needed. There are changes at all levels including compensation/salary changes. Another con is that in it's effort to catch up with the cloud market leaders, Google is becoming a traditional enterprise software company, and is loosing some of its values, culture, and identity.

headline: Google is great for the most part, but some things can be improved
pros:
Great facilities when in office, and great support to work from home (they pay for your WiFi, desk set up, accessories, etc.)
Status of being a Googler
Competitive salary
cons:
Career growth is encouraged only as much as it serves Google's goals, and once you're in the company, it's a bit difficult to really progress
Dissent is not encouraged, as much as they say it is an "open culture" - this stifles some of the best ideas, and keeps open discussions from happening
Promotion is a political process much more than it is merit-based

headline: All in all, an outstanding place to work.
pros:
* The employee's fight to keep the company as "good" as possible.
* The business model allows for the company to provide outstanding free services (gmail, calendar, maps, etc)
* It is on you to prove yourself for promotion (also a con) which means that managers don't unilaterally decide who should get promoted based on biases and favoritism.
cons:
* The employees have grown to expect to continue to be treated extremely well (pay, benefits, and perks).
* It is on you to prove yourself for promotion (also a pro) which leads to a "do what makes you look good, not do what is good" perspective.
* Because most people make a lot of money, there is a wealth culture that exists and that at least bothers me.

headline: The job is really not that interesting |The company really cares
pros:
- Perks are great and you will use them (gym, food, pantry, education, insurance, dental, ...)
- Working for a big company logo helps to open doors and makes you ''an interesting'' person in the room
- In the right team and with the right portfolio, you can make a real difference to businesses and communities
- Very empathetic, inclusive, and open environment
- Job safety. If you do your job, are on time, do what you're asked, it's a road to retirement

Generally, I'd recommend this job to someone in their mid-20s looking for a career in one company with a lot of resources, or an older individual with less drive looking for a safe place.
cons:
- Some roles are really not as glamorous as the job description reads. In customer-facing roles, you will often find yourself being an extended arm of Customer Support filing tickets and following up
- Getting a promotion is a steep challenge and fairly political (You have to be visible to the directors and sign up for all kinds of projects to show your value. This isn't much of an issue to me personally, but many people view it as an unwanted obstacle).
- You have to master your calendar to have time to actually do a job you want to do (After filing tickets, attending a dozen training sessions, taking multiple internal meetings a day, and replying to your emails, there are days when you find yourself having only 2-3 hours to do the job you hoped to be doing when they hired you)
- Inter-office transfers are very difficult to accomplish
- Irish tax system isn't really income-friendly (for those coming from low-income tax countries, you'd be shocked with how much money is lost every month).

Generally, I'd recommend dynamic, hungry, and entrepreneurial people to consider a smaller scale company where feel like you're making a difference, you mean something and your work is tangible, and not just a digit in Google's multi-billion dollar revenue.

headline: As tech jobs go It's pretty good but I'm not sure I personally like it here
pros:
- smart, kind, helpful coworkers who want to see you succeed! 
- lots and lots of possible stuff to work on internally, bc google really does Everything
- the perks + good job stability
- good work life balance; my workload is totally manageable
- cool to work on stuff that so many people use
cons:
- the company (and codebase) is so big it will swallow you whole if you are not careful
- getting promoted / "growing" in your career is a big corporate game which feels slimy at times, to me 
- takes forever to launch anything. sometimes you will work for months and months at a time on something and the project will get cancelled. it's fine when this happens once but when it happens several times in a row it can be disheartening
- the culture of your specific team & manager kind of defines your experience
- can feel like a cog in the machine

headline: Google UX Research PhD Internship
pros:
Lots of pros to working at Google as a PhD intern:
- Salary
- Benefits
- Company culture
- Resume boost + future opportunities
- Professional development and translation of skills to industry...
cons:
- Big company so you really need to be self-motivated to maximize your experience
- Often working longer than 9-5 to get projects done
- No ceiling on output (even though work life balance is encouraged) so you can end up working very hard

headline: Overall good work environment, highly team dependent though
pros:
Google is well known for its perks. In non-covid times the offices are well equipped, all the snacks, food, gyms, massage rooms, nap pods. It's the stuff of much satire. It's very nice.

The compensation is really good. Collaboration across teams can be great, although it does depend on product area. The culture in the company and much of the scandal that comes out is born out of transparency and freedom. Freedom to express yourself many employers stomp down on and sometimes.... it's too much but usually it's quite freeing.
cons:
The promotion process at google is well intentioned but poor, IMO. It is honestly probably the single biggest reason google is known for abandoning products. We develop things for promotions because that's what gets them. Maintaining and improving or spending the energy to rebuild and transfer data doesnt get you a promotion.

You need to land something, but you also need to excel for over a year this dissuades people pushing to do something to try and get a promotion which is good but also disincentivizing. The whole thing is political, you need to land grab at times to get work other teams might be doing so they can't do it.... again so you can get promoted. If you land in the right place at the right time it is easy to move up, rising tides raise all ships. A bad manager, a bad product idea, can sink you even if you are doing good work.

headline: Finding the balance.
pros: Google has great benefits (health insurance/vision/dental - all great), the facilities are amazing, employee perks and events are awesome. No one ever yells at you :)
cons: There does not seem to be a lot of true transparency. There are always emails from senior leads explaining things but comes off very politically advised. Internally mobility does not seem like what it use to be. It has been very difficult for people to advance their careers. Work life balance, especially during the pandemic has not been great.

headline: Scale is a Pro and a Con
pros: Scale up your impact by working for a company with billions of users, a culture that is focused on the right things, and brilliant coworkers.
cons: Changing a system with billions of users is harder than changing smaller systems. Google today is cautious, deliberative, and process heavy. Much of what makes an engineer successful at Google today is their ability to navigate the hierarchy, build consensus, and document everything. If you want to crank out code, iterate quickly, or focus on technical tasks Google is not the place for you.

headline: Generous to employees, hugely impactful to the world
pros:
Top tier compensation and benefits
Global company with lots of access to different culture, travel opportunities, recognition
Recognition for top performers
Incredible technology at hand for working at scale
cons:
Has become huge over time, way too much organizational complexity in recent years
Growth is stagnant in most areas in the last few years
Individual experiences vary wildly depending on background, location, teammates, managers, etc
Generally all tech is built in-house, strong not-invented-here culture, tech learned here doesn't transfer easily to future jobs

cons: Very big company to navigate.

headline: Great Launchpad to Senior Strategy Roles
pros: Gain experience generating millions of dollars and managing tens of millions more. Alumni from other parts of Alphabet come speak all the time, so internal transfers are pretty transparent. It's Google, so benefits are top of the top. Free gourmet food that changes every day (with some popular staples),  free dessert, free barista-made coffee, free snacks. And that's just the food, not to mention free gym, free rock climbing walls, free Ayco (Goldman Sachs) financial advice, free massages, etc. Plus, the people are super quirky, getting to know any one of them is so fascinating. There's always something that sticks out, like "oh! that's their special quirk". I remember my first day meeting people that came to Google from producing Emmy award-winning shows, are related to people that founded a literal sport, or have been to all continents. Google is full of incredibly smart people with interesting stories to tell.
cons: There are a crazy amount of benefits that its hard to keep track of. The main ones are listed and obvious but some more niche ones, or office-specific perks (like the free Lime scooters for some locations) are harder to find unless you spot the email. Maybe its more of a west coast office thing, but  people are very easy going. I kind of wish it were a bit more competitive and people would flex more. I'm proud of the work people are doing but they gotta speak up!

headline: Finding Impact in Your Niche
pros:
- Very competitive compensation, regular comp refresh 
- Smart coworkers, relatively horizontal structure (in sales) allows for collaboration
- No micromanagement, very flexible and balanced schedule 
- Opportunity to drive impact at scale, albeit in a very narrow part of the business 
- Ability to pursue new interests through 20% projects in other parts of the company 
- The best physical office environment you can imagine (personal trainers, peloton, lunch, etc.); some nice WFH covid perks to compensate in this time
cons:
- Massive company, lots of red tape to cut through when building anything new 
- Lost focus on the end-user in advertising sales, all about revenue numbers 
- Laborious promotion process, but yearly salary refresh helps with this 
- Very difficult to move between job ladders (ex. program mgmt vs. sales) despite outward appearance of career mobility; requires tenacity and patience to move around the company 
- "Googleyness" somewhat, but a more conventional company these days

headline: Great technological company marred by bureaucracy and politics
pros:
Salary might be high and various perks are nice. Depends a lot on the country / office you are in, though. A lot of smart people, computational resources and great (even if proprietary) tools for everything. The company carries the whole burden of your relocation. You have the ability to somewhat easily find a different project when you want and to move to that different team if you have spent 1-1.5 years on your current one. A lot of various projects to choose from.

If you are not a white heterosexual male, you get special attention from recruiters, also numerous internal support and career mentoring resources are at your disposal, so the company might be a good choice in that case.
cons:
Depending on the project and the team you might feel inefficient of even irrelevant due to projects being huge, old and slow. Despite all the talks about fighting biases etc, your future to a high degree depends on your manager, who is often a great engineer, but with the upsetting probability might be useless or even detrimental as a manager. Your future also depends more on your ability to demonstrate your work than to actually do something useful, which makes sense, but the company does not do a nearly good enough job teaching you how to perform such demonstration the way it is expected of you. Sometimes you have to choose between doing something useful for your team or something good for your "career". Having to stick to all those internal proprietary tools (that are otherwise great to have) makes it hard for you to do much if you leave the company and those tools behind.

You might end up in a team that won't be nearly a good match or might get a wrong role due to the recruiters making mistakes and then neither recruiters nor managers caring about fixing them.

HRs pretend to be your friends, but make no mistake - they are not. They only seem to care whether you are a potential issue to the company. If an issue might go away as a result of them bullying you - they might do that, as actually figuring out how to fix internal culture is harder than putting pressure on people.

The company keeps changing internal performance evaluation requirements, disrupting rythm of work on regular basis probably so someone up high might add "revamped evaluation process" etc to own resume at the cost of all the damage to the rest of the company. The CEO, Sundar Pichai, is great at photo ops, but otherwise uninspiring. The company's top management pushes American politics onto the rest of the company even if you are outside of the US. If you do not share radical left-wing American perceptions - either learn to stay silent or start searching for another job.

In 2019 there was a big situation where a bunch of black employees and their "allies" were harassing a white employee for that employee being unfortunate outside of work to call the police after noticing a black man who acted as a trespasser and who refused to leave. The top management of the company in a company-wide meeting "addressed" the situation by pledging their support to the black employees and said nothing at all that would prevent similar harassments in the future.

headline: Becoming more like IBM every year
pros: Google still attracts the best engineers, and they are a pleasure to work with. There are an incredible number of opportunities in all kinds of domains, and Google makes project and location transfers smooth and fast. In most countries, the compensation and benefits are top of market.
cons:
Google is on a downward trajectory, and it’s depressing. VP-level leadership doesn’t appear to understand the simple fact that processes have a cost, and it boggles the mind. Every new VP introduces more random process without ever worrying about the cost to time and morale, and then erects a wall of program managers and forms to insulate from any criticism or pressure to simplify.

Worse, most VP-mandated process is introduced because the VPs don’t trust middle management to do its job. Criticism and comments are discarded without response, and managers and directors I have spoken to are completely resigned.

The beatings continue until morale improves.

headline: Best firm for Software Developers!
pros:
Google offers free food, with various dining halls at the Googleplex catered to all kinds of cuisine. On a given day, there are options ranging from pasta to fresh sushi rolls, sandwiches, salads, and other kinds of Asian cuisine. There are even cafes at Google that allow employees to get a free coffee pick-me-up from a local third-wave cafe, on campus.
Google offers on-site physicians, nurses, medical services, and health care coverage to keep its employees happy and healthy. Googlers can travel without worries; employees are covered with travel insurance and emergency assistance on both personal and work-related vacations.
Google offers its employees one of the most innovative work environment cultures. Google cares so much about innovation, that one of its principles encourages Google employees to spend 20% of their time pursuing innovative ideas about which they are passionate. Products and applications, such as Google News, Google Alerts, and Google Maps Street View, have been born from this principle.
Google offers shuttle services to employees who work out of its Googleplex so they can avoid long wait times in traffic and even the stress of driving to work. Every morning, big black buses equipped with WiFi pick up employees to get to the office.
Google also offers some of the best paid parental leave for new parents. Its employees have paid leave up to 18 weeks if the father is the primary caregiver, or seven weeks otherwise. Mothers are still entitled to 22 weeks of maternity leave. Google cares so much about new parents that it offers parents one-on-one consultations to figure out their scheduling for daycare options, money to spend on baby bonding time, as well as four child care centers on one of its campuses.
Google also offers a Global Education Leave program, which enables employees to take a leave of absence to pursue further education. All of this education is covered by Google.
Since Google is one of the most well-known technology companies in the world, it offers employees better job prospects should they decide to leave the Googleplex. It also offers growth within the company, whether it be for middle management or higher-level management opportunities.
Working at Google provides employees with a sense of contributing to the worldwide population. Google employees positively impact society with the applications and technology on which they are working. These technologies would surely benefit the human race; for example, self-driving cars could enable its passengers to catch up on sleep during their commutes. Its accident rate is uncanny, with just a handful of accidents in the more than 20 million miles driven since January 2020, many of which were determined to be caused by human error.
Google only looks for the best and brightest minds, and employees are always exposed to other amazing employees and intelligent thinkers. Being around other intelligent thinkers allows for a creative work environment, collaboration, and disruptive innovation.
To help with morale, employees are free to bring their pets to work. Some Googlers describe that being able to bring their pets to work keeps their energy levels up, as well as bringing joy to other employees.
Although there are highly intelligent employees at Google, there is no rocket science that goes into Google offering one of the best work environments. Google simply treats people with respect and supports its employees' creative and innovative endeavors.
cons:
The competition is brutal.
Let’s face it: When you work for one of the biggest organisations in the world, your employer can easily afford to select the best – which makes for a highly competitive environment. When you work alongside some great talent, competition will be pretty much inevitable.

Learning is self-driven.
There is an expectation that you will actively continue to educate yourself and expand your knowledge as a Google employee. You are encouraged to commit to self-improvement as well as expanding your skills. Some might see this as an imposition on their time, but it is simply part of life in today’s ever-changing work environment – especially in technology – and many businesses have adopted a similar culture.

Launches drive advancement.
Google is known to promote staff as a result of product launches rather than as a reward for incremental improvements. Of course, in reality, most software developers will be involved in code improvement and bug fixing, yet the incentive scheme is not generally geared towards taking that into account.

Work-life balance – not always balanced.
Many modern American companies have developed a contrived culture of lingering at work. Ambitious, new or young talent may end up hanging out at the office outside of work hours, often working or learning. This can develop into peer pressure to spend a lot of time at the office. Apart from coffee shops and libraries, some places have “sleep pods” for that swift power nap to help you keep going for longer. The Toronto Office even has a crazy golf putting green on the roof!

headline: Big company - safe haven
pros:
- Strong hiring process ensures that the bar is in general fairly high. Of course there are always exceptions
- Decent benefits. Far better than rivals Amazon or Microsoft. But no match to other Bay Area counterparts such as Facebook or Netflix. 
- Bureaucracy is there. But the company tends to be data driven and makes tough decisions based on where the data points. Which means that the typical corporate fiefdom politics will have diminishing returns in the medium to long term.
cons:
- Big company. Which means the company culture is rather diluted in day to day experience. What really matters is the team, organization, manager and role that you sign up for
- Tough to make an impact as there are plenty of smart people around. This means the ones who are well entrenched in the system tend to perform better. As a new comer, don't expect immediate success
- Imposter syndrome is a real thing. But you need to remember that this is a well oiled machine and will function very well without any single individual. This includes even the CEO - Pichai. Yes, Google will run very well without him.
- Expect to be low balled in terms of salary/designation. Google has plenty of applicants. And they can always find a better person for the role at a cheaper price given enough time. So be ready to eat humble pie and join on the company's terms.

headline: Great people, good compensation, ladders and layers
pros:
Best people I've worked with - hands down. Really strong individual contributor engineers; technical leads care about their teams and have good product sense. 

Compensation is very good.
cons: Ladders optimize for risk reduction to the company - you must demonstrate sustained performance at next level in order to get promoted. This sounds reasonable but because you don't get an opportunity to demonstrate scope and skill at the next level because of the layers on top of you, it becomes a catch-22.

headline: Not what it used to be
pros: Comfortable, good place to coast and waste your life.
cons:
Career suicide, no meaningful work. 

Google is the new Microsoft/government job, bureaucracy to the very core. 

Your product/project will likely be cancelled, and it won't be a drop in the ocean. 95% of the staff is just reducing probable risk or cost or compliance work. Innovation is dead, and company is too marred by process to execute anything. Acquisition is Google's only remaining innovation strategy, which too takes 2-3 years. 

For those passionate about a tech career/impact I strongly recommend finding a real job instead (startup).

headline: Good benefits, bad everything else
pros:
Google pays reasonably well, and makes an effort to keep employees happy enough to stay.
The benefits are great, and the pay is competitive.
cons:
It is nearly impossible to transfer into engineering if you aren’t already there, and the company culture is very strange. You are expected to be friends with your coworkers, and you are expected to treat Google as though it is the best company in the world. 
The diversity and inclusion strategies are very tokenizing. As a queer person, I was immediately asked to get involved with diversity efforts. 
The culture also seems to be such that people like to pretend that Google is not a corporation that makes money.
Worth mentioning also that I was hired for a job description that had nothing to do with my actual role. 
They told me it was consulting but turns out it was product support. Big fat lie.
Also, the team I was on did things that were antithetical to the company’s “mission” and cloaked it under the guise of a necessary evil. 

Basically, unless they offer you a job as an engineer, avoid.

headline: A shell of it's former self
pros: Benefits are solid. Health, dental, yearly bonus, vacation, and pay raises are amazing.
cons:
The culture and environment has become a joke. Google was once the most sought after company for employment, but it has lost it's unique charm from over a decade ago. Now it's a corporate monster that has grown far too big. We were once the #1 company on Forbes' 100 best companies to work for and it hurt us deeply when we dropped to #2 after many years at the top. Fast forward to 2020 and we don't even make the top 100.

There is a serious lack of coherence and communication anymore. Motivation to succeed is not based on making great products, but instead on what you can do for promotion. This is clearly evident in the products we develop - or develop then abandon. It's also why we once had nine discrete messaging apps while many other products included messaging functions.

The world would be a better place if great ideas like Google Fiber, Stadia, and Voice were better executed. However, we're left with products that are not only made fun of by the public, but given countdown clocks to when they'll be discontinued. What remains are disjointed products like Gmail - including a UI so butchered and bloated, they needed to add a loading screen so you didn't think long loads times means the service is down. 

We once did great work and were on the top of the tech world. This is no longer the case and I doubt we could ever get there again. We're too large, too slow, too disparate, and have so many competing visions, that there is no return to our former glory days.

headline: Google
pros: Good first company name and experience will open doors
cons: Too hierarchical sometimes felt detached from objectives

headline: [For Google X] Your experience is highly dependent on your team
pros: Great food and snacks. Easy commute access being right next to the caltrain.
cons: X Labs is not very diverse unless you count asian and indian and it felt like most females were not on the engineering side. I was a contractor so can't speak to benefits. Your experience is HIGHLY dependent on your team and projects can come and go very quickly. It is very difficult to move from a contract to full-time position. Also the parking problem is terrible.

headline: Great company to settle down
pros:
- best perks in the tech industry
- great salary and equity compensation
- great work/life balance (depending on the team you work on)
- great job to have when you're ready to settle down, get a mortgage, have children, 9-5pm, work from home once/week, take lots of vacations. You will see people who have been working at Google like this for +10 years with very junior titles who are very happy. Success isn't always about the never-ending race to the top at work, spending time with families is also ok and Google provides the opportunities for that.
cons:
- Google sucks the best talent in the market, people who should be using their skills to be doing amazing, ground-breaking work to improve our society, are instead optimizing for how to get more clicks. You'll be surrounded by people who are way overqualified for the job they do but are only there because of the "golden cuffs" (the free food, the endless perks, and work/life balance). 
- eng vs. non-eng divide. Engineers get the best perks, salaries, off-sites, offices, etc. If you are not engineer, you're disposable, master degrees in anything else but computer science don't really have any weight here. MBAs won't automatically give you a different title or responsibilities at Google than a college grad.
- Really hard to move laterally once you have reached the plateau of your learning curve. If you're no longer challenged or happy with your job, why invest in you when they have hundreds of people lined up to take your job?
- no diversity among senior management (few women or people of color who are, in turn, not interested in raising people up the career ladder).

headline: Overall a great place to work but growth varies by team
pros:
-Collaborative, smart people to work with
- Benefits are amazing, I don't have to worry about changing circumstances (for e.g. carer's leave during covid-19) 
- Performance reviews really try to be fair and equitable
cons:
- Organizational complexity sometimes creates misaligned incentives 
- Growth opportunities, workload and culture often vary greatly by team but it's easy to move across teams

headline: Great company where personal growth can stagnate
pros:
Amazing people
Great perks
Lots of fun problems to work on
3/5 bosses were excellent, 1/5 bosses was good (and the other would show up in the cons)
RSU stock grants were amazing. If you stay at Google for a few years, those RSUs really start to stack.
cons:
Sales job (initial entry level job) became boring pretty quick - lots of sales reps tried to move into product / strategy roles (with good reasons I think)
Google is now just a big company - there's lots of people and a competitive talent pool. This makes getting stretch opportunities a rarity.
Lots of distraction from day-to-day work with protests against Google in China, DoD deals, sexual harassment, etc. While the sexual harassment protests were definitely merited and Andy Rubin was absolutely in the wrong, I thought there was frequently more negativity than was warranted against the company that fed you 3x/day, paid you handsomely, and gave you the chance to interact with other amazing people.

headline: Misaligned ladders, obscene hours, inaccessible perks. Stable employment but misrepresented.
pros: Stable employment. People are not typically fired abruptly, and have opportunity to move teams. Less formal office environment. Intelligent and capable coworkers. Flexibility in schedule and role.
cons:
Perks and role requirements blatantly misrepresented and greatly exceed contract. You better learn to do everything; code, manage, lead, but without corresponding comp. Long hours that bleed into personal life.

Core contributions marginalized in favor of "grand visions". Professional advancement artificially suppressed by committee. Zero long-term vision or commitment. When contacted about discrepancy in offer, HR blamed recruiter and "walked back" written promises about total comp after contract was signed.

Original "Googley" company culture, benefits, innovation has been killed in name of cost efficiency and scale. Company actively discriminates against conservative viewpoints.

Great perks: free food, gym onsite, etc. Very stable and secure job (even during covid). It will look good on your resume forever if you can get here! I'd say try to get in and work a few years to build your skillset but if you don't get a good project then move on.
cons: So many smart and ambitious people who want to do the Next Great Thing that it can be hard to get a chance to work on a good project. Some people can get lost in the shuffle. It is a Big Company. The interview to get in is a bit of a lottery-- lots of super smart people don't get in on the first try... or second try.

headline: Google is Evil!
pros: Free Food, Bonus, RSU, Nothing else
cons:
Google hiring is the most ridiculous process ever - Its a joke! they make you go through 3 months of crazy interviews with dumb questions. You keep your life on hold for things to pan out.

Next they will downlevel you even if you do really well in interviews cus they want to low ball you! Interviewers dont want to see anyone joining from a non FAANG company at a higher level they joined!

Once you are past these stages and are at the finishing line - You are told that the position is eliminated! 

 You make things more complicated then they should be and exploit job seekers. Take this somewhere else - Pathetic!

headline: Best company I’ve worked at
pros:
Google is the bets company I worked at. The benefit and perks is without doubt very attractive.
The culture is very free and flexible, and it’s very ground up company. 
Management is more like a adviser to coach you on career development, and give us the freedom to do what we want to do to enhance our career. 
Even during the covid-19, Google pay attention to our well being, we have 1000$ to purchase WFH furnitures and they even give free holidays  to take care of ourselves. 
I’m very lucky I’m working at Google.
cons: Sometimes, thing could move slower than expected as Google is growing to be a giant company. But it’s not a big deal, overall the speed and efficiency is much faster than any other firms I’ve worked at.

headline: Solid Experience, would work again
pros:
- Highly competitive pay, best benefits I've seen, best perks I've seen (yes, this doesn't matter, but when everything else is good, this helps).
- Very strong individuals. The average engineer here is very skilled and some of the best in the industry are here. This does not mean everyone is a genius, but there are certainly some here. To do the work, you definitely don't need to be the best, but the quality here is definitely among the best I've seen (I've worked at other "top" companies).
- Stellar work life balance. I've seen reviews for this that are negative, but I feel like they're on the wrong team or something. My team was busier than most and promoted people quickly and I still rarely pushed over 40 hours a week. I've seen some people work significantly fewer hours as well and still progressed. You can coast at L4 if you just do basic work and rest and vest.
- Good projects if you're on the right team. If you get lucky and get on the right team then the work is definitely interesting. This can be a con if you are on the wrong team.
- Interesting tools and learning opportunities. You can definitely learn a lot about system architecture if you are new to it. You can learn about any product area and go into the little details of that domain. Some tools at Google are used elsewhere and the knowledge can be transferred (Guice, Bazel, gRPC, protos, etc).
cons:
- Work does not translate to other jobs. You never get to work on stuff like Apache Spark, AWS S3, RabbitMQ, and other technologies that are very common in industry. Instead you learn things like BigTable, which is similar to Apache HBase but not exactly. Your knowledge of internal frameworks is mostly useless in other jobs. The concepts learned are not, however.
- Half the projects are objectively boring and stale. Most of the projects are maintaining some aspect of the system (cloud, ads, etc) and a lot of it is tedious infrastructure work.
- Office politics as usual. The general population is friendly, but this does not mean everyone. Office politics definitely do play a role.

headline: "Cloud Singapore - Poisonous snakepit"
pros:
Compensation package (management offering us relief in COVID era)
Cloud products (cutting edge platform, destroyed by lack of management reality checks)
cons:
- Regional management and politics
(Leaders hired mostly from AWS bringing AWS processes and culture. Leaders criticize constantly and do not offer tangible solutions all the while claiming credit for work they do not do.)
- Promotions/Development - Old boys club (if you are tight with APAC management, ex aws, can coast, not do a thing, be none the wiser and get paid)
- Lack of direction
We spend too much time to make plans and do not meet customers as much as we would like to. Conflicting directions or lack of from teams.
